business.start.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Paul Calvert) took the chair at 12.30 p.m. and read prayers.

subdebate.2.para: Senator MACKAY (Tasmania) (12.31 p.m.)—by leave—At the request of the Chair of the Select Committee on the Free Trade Agreement between Australia and the United States of America, Senator Cook, I move:

motion.para: That the Select Committee on the Free Trade Agreement between Australia and the United States of America be authorised to hold a public meeting during the sitting of the Senate today, from 3.30 pm.

debateinfo.title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT (PERSONAL INCOME TAX REDUCTION) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Senator IAN CAMPBELL (Western Australia—Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads) (12.32 p.m.)—I move:

motion.para: That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

subdebate.1.para: Question agreed to.
Bill read a first time.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator IAN CAMPBELL
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

para.inline: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT (PERSONAL INCOME TAX REDUCTION) BILL 2004

quote.para: The measures contained in this bill will cut personal income tax by $14.7 billion over four years. The tax reductions will be delivered by increasing the income thresholds for the top two tax brackets. These changes are specifically targeted at encouraging Australians to increase their workforce participation.

The prospect of moving to a higher tax bracket can act as a disincentive for increased workforce participation. At present, the 42 per cent marginal tax rate cuts in at incomes that are a multiple of around 1.1 male average earnings and the 47 per cent marginal tax rate cuts in around 1.3 male average earnings.
Australians earning the equivalent of fulltime adult average earnings will cross the 42 per cent tax threshold in 2004-2005 unless the threshold is increased significantly as proposed in this bill.
The amendments in this bill will remedy this structural weakness in the personal income tax schedule.

These targeted changes to the personal income tax schedule will ensure that the majority of Australian taxpayers—over 80 per cent across the forward estimate years—will remain in or below the 30 per cent tax bracket.

Generally speaking, Australia's personal income tax system is internationally competitive. Australia is presently ranked as the sixth lowest taxing nation in the OECD. However, Australia is uncompetitive internationally in terms of the low income threshold at which its highest marginal tax rates cut in.

Many highly skilled Australians—including our young people—are internationally mobile and can choose to work anywhere in the world. It is important that the tax system does not encourage Australians to leave our country and our workforce, nor discourage talented people from other countries from coming to work in Australia.
Lifting the top two tax thresholds will ensure that Australia strengthens its international position as a low-taxing nation.
The tax cuts in this bill are critical to promoting workforce participation and productivity so that Australia can meet its demographic challenges.
Full details of the measures in this bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum. I commend the bill.

talk.start.para: —Although Labor will not oppose the Tax Laws Amendment (Personal Income Tax Reduction) Bill 2004, I must take this opportunity to condemn the government for producing a budget that has failed dismally to meet the high expectations of the people of Australia. In the lead-up to this budget hopes were very high that this government would provide broad based relief for Australian families burdened by the highest-taxing government in history with record debt—relief to compensate households for the effect of bracket creep. But the hopes of these families that they would finally get serious tax reform have been dashed. Instead this budget has created a class of forgotten people.

speech.para: Before I go to the detail of how this budget has failed on the tax reform front, I remind the Senate of the Treasurer's track record. He is hardly the friend of the taxpayer. In eight years Mr Costello's record on tax relief is providing a tax cut to compensate for the GST and, after that, we had the smallest tax cut in our history. Remember last year that insulting sandwich and milkshake tax cut? So what now? For 80 per cent of taxpayers, that is four out of five Australians, this budget gives nothing—not a cent of tax relief. But so great is the cynicism that the electorate holds towards this Treasurer that they are not surprised. They are used to getting stung by the highest-taxing Treasurer in Australia's history.

Despite the tax cuts in this bill, total tax revenue will hit a record high next year of $217 billion. That is up 90 per cent since 1996. By next year, total personal income tax will be up 80 per cent since the government came to office. That is right, 80 per cent. Australian taxpayers are now paying an aver-age of $9,000 more in Commonwealth taxes than in 1996. and this will grow to $12,000 over the forward estimates. Australians have got used to carrying the weight of Mr Costello's ever increasing tax burden.

Let us look a bit closer at what this bill does—and fails to do. For taxpayers earning less than $52,000 a year there is no tax relief. In the seat of Brisbane 78,500 people do not get a tax cut. That is 83 per cent of the taxpayers in the seat of Brisbane. In the seat of Cunningham 74,800 do not get tax relief. That is 86 per cent of electors in Cunningham who do not get a tax cut. In the seat of McMillan 70,900 do not get a tax cut. That is 93 per cent of taxpayers in McMillan get nothing in tax cuts in this budget. According to NATSEM, three out of five families and singles will miss out on the tax cuts and the family assistance benefits. A majority of families get nothing at all from the budget in any form. The tax cuts in the budget fail to even give back bracket creep in any year over the forward estimates.

There are seven new taxes or increases in existing taxes in this budget. This brings the total to 151 since this government came to office. That is right: 151 new or increased taxes since this government came to office in 1996. At least one out of three families eligible for family tax benefit may never see the second family tax payment of $600. The Minister for Children and Youth Affairs and the Treasurer have both now admitted it will be clawed back to pay debts. Here was a budget which outlined a record $52 billion spending spree but failed to offer any restoration of basic services and hardly anyone got any tax cuts.

There was no plan in the budget to save Medicare, make education more affordable or address the long-term savings and investment needs of this nation. The Treasurer calculated—or rather miscalculated—that Labor would not pass these tax cuts. He thought that Labor would oppose the tax changes in this bill for higher income earners. He focused on the $52 billion he was going to splurge on his government's desperate attempt to cling to power. But he did not realise that Australians would focus on the other 52—those earning under $52,000 who do not get a single cent from tax cuts in this bill. Mr Costello's tax gamble has not paid off, and the losers are the four out of five Australian taxpayers who have been left behind.

While Mr Costello miscalculated his tax package, Australian families have been forced to calculate how much tougher life has become. Household debt is at a record high and, on average, our families owe more than they earn. The household debt to income ratio is now at 147 per cent. Credit card debt has become the main currency for too many families. Mortgage repayments are chewing more of the family budget than ever before. The costs of going to see a doctor and of giving our kids a higher education are skyrocketing. To add insult to injury, the government's own family payments system is creating a debt trap for too many of our families. Families under record financial stress need relief. Labor have consistently argued that we can provide this relief by (1) restoring vital services like bulk-billing, creating 20,000 new places in our TAFEs and 20,000 places in our universities while reversing the 25 per cent Howard-Costello fee hike and (2) providing broader and fairer tax relief. You can fund better services without raising overall tax levels if you make the tough decisions to redirect current expenditure.

Contrary to the naivety of some reports, all Labor's spending is fully costed and fully funded. It is not additional spending. It is redirected spending and it is paid for through savings—savings from cutting the waste and mismanagement that are fast becoming the hallmarks of this government. Only this fiscal rigour gives you the ability to sustain better services for families and lower charges for people. Under Labor's fiscal rules we are funding our proposed spending on services in a way that will drive down expenditure to GDP and maintain surpluses. This is a reformist approach to our public finances and one that will ultimately benefit all Australians.

In contrast, Mr Costello has given up on reform. The real tragedy of this budget is that the Treasurer has missed a golden opportunity to drive significant reform to the current tax system. He has missed a chance to try to reduce the disincentives created by the interaction of the tax and social security systems. None of the fundamental problems with the system—the need for relief for ordinary workers under record financial stress, the crippling disincentives to work and the family debt trap—have been addressed in this budget. We are still left with many families facing serious disincentives to work. They keep working harder, but they keep being held back by crippling effective marginal tax rates. This will ultimately lead to lower productivity, lower growth and lower living standards. That is a price that we should not have to ask our children to pay.

Fundamental reform of the family payments system is needed to avoid the massive debt trap that it creates. But the government just sits on its hands. At the last election, the Prime Minister said he would fix the debt trap once and for all. He offered a one-off $1,000 bribe to pay off the debts in order to buy his way through the election. Here we are, three years later, on the eve of another election and Mr Howard covers up his broken promise to fix the system with another bribe—another patch-up. This is not genuine reform.

Labor will offer an alternative. We will provide broader and fairer tax relief. We will make the tax system work for Australians, not against them. The details of Labor's tax plan will be released at a time of our choosing, but we will give people plenty of time to compare our package with that offered by the government. With record tax collections, a peaking of participation in the labour force and 13 years of economic growth, this was the opportunity for reform, and Australians expected it. Instead of serious tax reform we got a seriously large election bribe. Instead of support for Australian families we got a tax cut which ignored four out of five Australian taxpayers. This is not a plan for a better Australia; it is just a plan for an election. However, Australians can see through it. They will reject this budget due to the inherent unfairness of this taxation bill and the contempt with which this Treasurer treats struggling ordinary people, who are again required to prop up the misguided policies of this highest-taxing government in Australia's history.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Tax Laws Amendment (Personal Income Tax Reduction) Bill 2004. In November 2003 I wrote an opinion piece for a newspaper and I am going to repeat some of the things I said there. Last November I said:

quote.para: Big tax cuts are now inevitable.

Labor has ensured it by endlessly rabbiting on about the Coalition being the highest-taxing Australian government ever. (True but irrelevant, since Australia is among the lowest-taxing nations in the OECD.)
Labor's line is dangerous. It encourages a resistance to raising additional revenue to invest in education, health and the environment.
The Liberals have guaranteed tax cuts by constantly saying surpluses must be paid back.
So the question is: When?

My bet is in the May budget. One reason is that such an election sweetener is irresistible for the government. Two, the Coalition would want to spend any surplus money in advance, leaving Labor with nothing to promise. Three, pay packets would only benefit from tax cuts legislation in the second half of next year, when an election is most likely. Four, tax cuts will be seen as some relief against expected higher interest rates.
The government have trapped Mark Latham into virtually guaranteeing Labor support for raising the present top tax rate of 48.5 per cent from $62,500 to a much higher threshold.
ACOSS say anyone earning $100,000 has an average tax rate of 34 per cent on all income. Is that really that high?

The well-off have already had their tax cuts. The Coalition's 30 per cent rebate on private health insurance, costing the taxpayer nearly $3 billion a year, favours higher income earners. Capital gains tax was halved just a few years ago, with Labor support, despite the Democrats' opposition and despite the fact that it clearly mainly benefited those wealthy Australians with investment and share portfolios.

Democrats like me can cry all they like that Commonwealth revenue and expenditure are still insufficient to meet the pressing and legitimate expectations and needs of Australians for health, education and the environment, amongst other things. (Health will remain an issue, even if Medicare Plus passes the Senate.)
We say we do not so much need increased taxes as increased revenue. We attack some tax expenditures and tax wastage as the means of assisting the growth in revenue to meet expenditure needs.
But tax cuts it will be. The two majors will have the numbers.
So, if tax cuts seem inevitable, what is the right way to go? What could or should be the government priorities and how much money would they have to spend?

speech.para: That is what I wrote in November 2003. This bill introduces the tax cuts that I forecast and that were announced by the Treasurer on budget night. And, like most Australians, I was astonished on budget night when I heard that tax cuts costing $14.7 billion over four years would be given only to those earning over $52,000 a year. This seemed crazy brave for a government facing an election year and a government which had enough money to contemplate an infinite number of tax cut possibilities. For 2004-05, higher income earners will get a $21 a week tax cut; for 2005-06, it will be $42 a week or $2,184 per annum.

While tax relief for earners below, say, $100,000, particularly at middle-income levels, is argued by many to be justified, in our view the first call should have been to give relief to low and lower middle-income earners. Only 24 per cent, or 2.25 million taxpayers, will benefit from this tax cut. The government have justified the legislation on the basis that it ensures that 80 per cent of taxpayers will have a maximum nominal tax rate of 30 per cent or less. This has long been a policy objective of theirs.

Judging by the media and by calls to our offices, it does seem that these tax cuts have not generated anger of real note. In that sense, the government has taken a risk that it seems to have calculated well. But it appears that Australians do not really resent tax cuts to those earning above $52,000. What those earning below $52,000 do resent is the fact that they did not get tax cuts too, especially single parents without children, who are left out of the budget pork. The Democrat amendments that I will move later will provide a tax cut to the deserving seven million taxpayers who will be getting nothing from the government's exclusive tax cut for higher income earners. We are not saying that those earning $60,000 or $70,000 a year are rich; they are not. We get plenty of correspondence from families on this income level explaining the cost of raising children. They often feel like they are struggling, particularly in some of the big cities like Sydney. I can understand their perspective and we are not saying that they should pay more tax—they do deserve a bit of a tax cut, too, which our proposal would deliver—but this group must remember that they are, from an income perspective, in the top 20 per cent of earning Australians and they should remember that the average full-time wage earner is still earning below the $52,000 a year that this tax cut uses as a benchmark. They should remember that there are around seven million Australians earning less than $20,000 who do not get a tax cut.

Tax cuts only for higher income earners are considered offensive by many Australians. The highest effective tax rates continue to be paid by low-income Australian families, who should be helped to stop them falling into poverty traps. If you wanted to get people off welfare and into work, you would target the tax and welfare intersects. The working class and the middle class get the rawest income tax deal. Low and lower income Australians struggle with the tax threshold that kicks in at a ridiculously low level of $6,000 and they struggle with the highest effective tax rates of all because, as they earn more, welfare benefits are reduced.

The most important distributive mechanism for improving the lot of low-income Australians is to improve their disposable income. From the employer's perspective, if the disposable income of low-wage earners increases as a result of tax cuts, it could take some of the stress and tension off the low wage industrial case that has to be mounted through the Australian Industrial Relations Commission every year. The Democrats believe that all Australians should get a tax cut, but it must be a fair and equal tax cut. That is the purpose of our amendment. Unfortun-ately, the government only want to help the higher income earners in this budget, and that is their priority.

I note that shortly after the Australian government budget, the New Zealand government announced their proposals. Like Australia, families were winners in that budget, but there were no tax cuts in New Zealand. Instead, the New Zealand government included an interesting $60 a week payment for in-work, low-income families. Their aim is to increase the incentives of people to move from welfare to work. The very senior and longstanding reporter—and very serious reporter, I might say—Tim Colebatch, in the Age of 1 June 2004, said:

quote.para: This is the first stage of welfare reforms that the NZ Government intends to culminate by tackling the hardest issue of welfare reform: merging the welfare system into a single welfare benefit with add-ons to meet particular needs, as recommended in Australia in 2000 by the sadly neglected McClure report on welfare reform.

speech.para: He went on:

quote.para: Welfare payments with high clawbacks are poverty traps. Any reformers worth the name, in government or opposition, should make it a top priority to cut those claws, so that for people on welfare, work will pay.

speech.para: It is a shame that the Australian government did not believe that this was a priority worthy of tackling in this budget, particularly since it welcomed the McClure report, which had this kind of strategy in mind.

Turning to other parties' approaches to the tax cuts and tax cuts generally, the approach of the Australian Greens is to deny everyone a tax cut. The Greens' policy is not to give tax relief to low-income earners. Last year, in fact, they voted against the low-income earners' tax cuts. The Greens do share the Democrats' concern that the government is not spending enough on health and education, but their simple rhetoric has ignored the reality that a fair tax cut not only would help low-income earners but is necessary for low-income earners. It also ignores the fact that there were cash surpluses of $7.5 billion last year and there will still be, despite the massive handout to buy votes from families this month, $4.6 billion this year.

Despite the fact that we have seen cash surpluses of $12 billion in the last two years alone, Australians believe services continue to deteriorate. They feel that this government is never going to fund health and education sufficiently and that their surpluses are going to be put in the bank and used to pay off debt—despite the fact that Australia's debt level is exceptionally low by historical standards and amazingly low compared to any international standards. Providing a fair tax cut to those most in need would not hurt our fiscal policy or the massive budget surplus.

Prior to the budget, the Democrats announced that, if there were to be tax cuts, we would prefer to see an increase in the tax-free threshold from $6,000 to $10,000, thus providing an equal tax cut to all taxpayers. Obviously this would benefit lower income earners proportionately more. As I have said, this bill will provide a tax cut only to those earning over $52,000 a year at a cost of around $15 billion over four years, giving a $42 a week or $2,184 per annum tax cut in 2005-06. Only 24 per cent, or 2.25 million, of Australian taxpayers will benefit, and there is nothing for the other seven-odd million. What the Democrats seek to do, with an amendment which hopefully we will circulate soon, would cost roughly the same as the government's proposal. Our proposal would increase the bottom tax threshold from $6,000 to $7,500 in 2004-05 and to $9,000 in 2005-06. This would give all of the over nine million Australian taxpayers around $5 a week in tax cuts in 2004-5, which is $260 per annum, and $10 a week the following year, which would be $520 per annum—in both cases, $260 more in year one and $520 more in year two than the lower income earners are going to get at present.

If the tax cut proposal was designed to wedge Labor in preparation for an election, it has worked. Mr Latham has been constantly talking about broader and fairer tax cuts, but he is yet to reveal an alternative proposal. I note that, once again, that was not on the table today. This is his chance, we think, to show what Labor does stand for. We urge the Labor Party to commit to broader income tax cuts for all Australians, with an emphasis on lower- and middle-income Australians, and, in this instance, to support the Democrats' fair and equal tax cuts proposals. Labor senators, who have been so critical of the government's tax policy—so opposed to the wonderful initiative of the GST and the new tax system, so opposed to earning revenue, so critical of how little is spent on health and education—still will not commit to an alternative tax cut view. We think they should not just let these tax cuts sail through the Senate. We think Labor should be putting an alternative through, in the sense of either supporting our proposals or putting up its own proposals. We can amend these bills and we should.

If Labor in the Senate does support Mr Costello's idea of a fair tax cut, it will be another step towards the `soft target' strategy which we think has failed Labor previously. I will speak further to my amendments in the committee stage, but I want to move on to asking Treasury and the government, whichever it will be next time round, to start thinking with some imagination. In the second reading speech on this bill is this statement:

quote.para: The prospect of moving to a higher tax bracket can act as a disincentive for increased work force participation. At present the 42 per cent marginal tax rate cuts in at incomes that are a multiple of around 1.1 male average earnings, and the 47 per cent marginal tax rate cuts in at around 1.3 male average earnings.

speech.para: I think that that observation from the Treasurer is an accurate one. I think what the Treasurer is saying is that the way in which inflation and tax policy have allowed the bands to concentrate and converge and allowed people who are relatively low earners to pay the highest tax rate is a legitimate complaint. I do not think that the way this has been addressed either last year or this year by the government or the way I have heard Labor discussing this matter addresses the fundamental problem: we need a quantum shift in permanently adjusting tax rates so that people can be certain and secure in their perception of their fairness, equity and longevity.

There is only one way to do that, and that is with wholesale reform. I am not suggesting that what I am about to say is the answer but I want to speculate and see what it would look like. Let us say, for instance, that the tax system was accepted as needing to be progressive and that the same number of income tax rates was retained—there are five at present. One of the reforms that Labor introduced in its time in government was, of course, to reduce the huge number of bands—I forget the number, but I suspect it was several dozen—down to five. Let us say we accept that principle. Then let us say we accept the Democrats' view that in good tax policy, in order to ensure that lower income people will be free from tax, we should look at a tax-free threshold of $20,000. Let us assume an upper income tax threshold of $120,000—that would leave $100,000 between those two, with three tax brackets within that. And let us assume that the top tax rate is at or near what it is at present. It might rise a little to be 50 per cent at the top rate, but that is not a big deal. The way to ensure that that gets locked in, of course, is to index the lowest and the highest tax rates so that every year they move up to adjust for inflation. Then periodically governments can address the intervening tax and welfare intersects as they see fit over time. But at least the constancy and relativity would be maintained by indexing the top and bottom thresholds.

I have had a look at what the costings would be—of course, I do not have access to the giant machines and all the modelling that the government has access to, so I know the Senate will recognise that what I am about to say is an estimate based on rough scheduling. But, if you were to introduce such a system—based on three tax rates of perhaps 25 per cent, 30 per cent and 40-odd per cent—you would get a tax cost of around $52 billion over three years. That is the sort of figure you would face if you were really to attempt to permanently reform our tax system—on the basis that you introduce permanent rates and indexing, and a progressive system to ensure that the relativities are maintained. When I quoted the Treasurer earlier, what he was indicating was that the relativities have slipped and that Australians feel aggrieved that they are no longer being taxed fairly. In the next government somebody has to grasp this nettle, even while recognising the very great cost that is entailed in addressing it properly.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Tax Laws Amendment (Personal Income Tax Reduction) Bill 2004. There can be no doubt that the hardworking Australians who earn more than $52,000 per annum are entitled to a tax cut. But the heart of this matter is whether Australians who earn less than $52,000 are also entitled to tax relief. This government, in one of the most cynical exercises in Australian history, has engaged in the most blatant vote-buying round of tax cuts ever seen—targeted at the few and not at the many. There can be no doubt that these tax cuts are not worth a cent to most Australians. Indeed, according to official statistics, there are no tax cuts for four out of every five taxpayers. By any objective measure, having 80 per cent of people miss out on these tax cuts fails this Prime Minister's 1996 promise to govern for all of us. Instead, he governs for some at the expense of all of us.

speech.para: Take one very simple exercise as a case in point. As former Prime Minister Paul Keating once said, you should always back self-interest because at least you know it is trying. I, like all senators and members, employ staff. I chose to have a flat structure, with all my staff employed as electorate officers grade B. The injustice of these tax cuts can have no clearer example. Personally, as with all other senators and members, I will get a tax cut. There will be tax relief for parliamentarians because we earn over the magic $52,000 per year. But there will not be one cent of tax relief for any of the people who work with me in my office. This, of course, illustrates the failure of these tax cuts. I work with these people day after day, and the government is telling me that I can have a tax cut but that no-one else in my office can.

Now the basic defence that the government offers as to why it has failed to deliver tax cuts to 80 per cent of Australians is that these people will be looked after through the family tax payments. That premise only holds up if those people are eligible for family tax payments in the first place. If you are a family where both you and your partner work yet do not earn more than $52,000 per year then, even with dependent children, you get nothing from this government. If you are a self-funded retiree, you miss out. If you have not had children, you miss out. If you are single, you miss out.

Some commentators have referred to the 80 per cent of Australians who will not get a tax cut as the `forgotten people'. I grant it is a strong term but I contend that in this case it is not an appropriate one. The Howard government can hardly claim that they have forgotten these people. A more correct term would be the `ignored people'. There can be no doubt that that 80 per cent have been deliberately ignored by this government. How do you forget 80 per cent of Australians? The government made a conscious decision to not provide tax relief to these people. They simply weighed up the odds and decided that giving tax relief only to those Australians earning more than the magic $52,000 a year would boost their re-election prospects. Let there be no doubt that they chose to give to the few at the expense of the many.

Indeed, we do not have to look beyond the figures from the last census, of 2001. The ABS data shows that in most electorates more than 80 per cent of people will receive not a cent in tax relief. Let us look at the figures for the electorates in my home state of Western Australia. In the electorate of O'Connor, one of the safest Liberal seats in Western Australia, 93 per cent will not qualify for a tax cut. Perhaps this is yet another example of the inability of the member for O'Connor to represent the interests of his constituents. After all, he will get a tax cut. There will be tax relief for him and for only a paltry seven per cent of those in his electorate. What about the other safe Liberal seats in Western Australia? In Tangney only 14 per cent of people will get a tax cut. In Forrest only nine per cent will get any relief. In Kalgoorlie a massive 20 per cent will get tax relief. In Moore 13 per cent will get tax relief, and in Pearce nine per cent will. In Curtin 21 per cent of people will receive the tax cut. These figures demonstrate that the overwhelming number of Australians, even in the government's own electorates, are going to miss out. In one of the most marginal seats in the country, the seat of Canning, the Prime Minister and his Treasurer have failed to help even 20 per cent. In Canning 90 per cent will miss out.

The ALP seats in Western Australia do not even reach the lofty heights of the figures for the electorates of Curtin and Kalgoorlie. In fact, the highest percentage of Western Australians in Labor seats receiving a tax cut is only just reaching double figures. In Fremantle, it is 11 per cent; in Perth, 11 per cent; in Swan, 10 per cent; in Stirling, 10 per cent; in Cowan, nine per cent; and in both Brand and Hasluck, eight per cent. That is not good enough by any measure. The government cannot claim that those people who will miss out will be accommodated under the family tax payments system. For those with no dependent kids, there will be no family tax assistance. For those with dependent kids over 18, there will be no family tax assistance. The government pretend that the tax cuts are not the whole picture, and in that they are right. The whole picture has to include all those people the government chose to ignore. The full picture includes all Australians, and the fact is that across the country 80 per cent of them do not get any relief from this government.

The ABS census statistics show that those electorates that do best out of this government are all safe Liberal seats in—surprise, surprise!—Sydney and Melbourne. In North Sydney, 35 per cent will get a tax cut; in Wentworth, 30 per cent—and I bet they will be glad to have their new member, whomever that will be—in Bradfield, 29 per cent; in Higgins, 26 per cent; in Kooyong, 24 per cent; in Mitchell, 24 per cent; in Goldstein, 22 per cent; in Berowra, 22 per cent; and so it goes on. I find it interesting that in the Prime Minister's own electorate 81 per cent will not get a tax cut but in the electorate he now chooses to live in—that is, North Sydney—only 65 per cent will miss out. Talk about ignoring the people that put you there. Now comfortably living in the electorate of North Sydney, he looks after his new neighbours but ignores his constituents. That is not really fair. He ignores 81 per cent of the people he is meant to represent.

These tax cuts were designed to deliver a fourth term to the Howard government. They are a failure by any measure of justice or equity. They are designed to buy votes—pure and simple. The tax relief in this budget is not designed to put fairness or equity back into the taxation system. As Senator Conroy said, it is not even designed to restore bracket creep. It does not address the needs of single Australians, couples with no children or self-funded retirees. It is a tax cut for a few of us, given in the hope that all of us will be subjected to another three years of Howard government policy drift. That is what these tax cuts are designed for. They are designed so that there will be two more years of neglect and clawback followed by a spending binge in yet another election year. The Australian people are now aware of the cruel frauds that have been perpetuated on them over the last eight years. What they wanted was a government for all of them, and that is what the Prime Minister championed. What they now have is a government for a few of them, for less than 20 per cent of them. They have a government that has not forgotten about them but has deliberately chosen to ignore them.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Sport

talk.start.para: —The Tax Laws Amendment (Personal Income Tax Reduction) Bill 2004 gives effect to the reductions in personal income tax announced in the 2004-05 budget and is part of a package to help 99.8 per cent of Australian families with children. The measures contained in this bill will cut personal income tax by some $14.7 billion over four years. The tax reductions will be delivered by increasing the income thresholds for the top two tax brackets. These changes are targeted to ensure that the tax system continues to support rewards from working. The prospect of moving to a higher tax bracket can be a disincentive to increased work force participation. Australians earning the equivalent of full-time adult average earnings will cross the 42 per cent threshold in 2004-05 unless the threshold has increased significantly, as proposed in this bill.

speech.para: These targeted changes to the personal income tax schedule will ensure that the majority of Australian taxpayers—over 80 per cent, across the forward estimate years, including those on average earnings—will remain in or below the 30 per cent tax bracket. These changes will also make the Australian tax system more internationally competitive. Many highly skilled Australians, including our young people, are internationally mobile and can choose to work anywhere in the world. It is important that the tax system does not discourage talented people from living and working in Australia. Lifting the top tax threshold will ensure that Australia strengthens its international position as a low taxing nation. The significant increase in the top tax threshold will improve Australia's ability to compete as a preferred place to live and work.

The tax cuts in this bill build on the income tax cuts the government delivered through its A New Tax System and in the 2003-04 budget. The combined effect of these three stages of tax reform is to deliver significant tax cuts to all Australians. There will be a 23 per cent reduction in tax for taxpayers earning around $20,000 a year compared to the amount of tax people on this income would have paid prior to A New Tax System. This is a very substantial tax cut—of course, those who remember the debate on A New Tax System recall how the Labor Party fought these tax cuts tooth and nail. There will be a 21 per cent reduction in tax for taxpayers earning $50,000 a year, which is around average earnings; and an 18 per cent reduction in tax for taxpayers earning around $90,000, after the tax cuts in this bill are implemented.

It is important to keep in mind that people who do not pay tax cannot benefit from tax cuts. On current estimates there are about 6.8 million people aged 16 and over who do not pay any tax. A single adult does not pay tax until their taxable income reaches $7,383. This effective threshold will be higher if they receive an allowance or a pension. About 6.8 million people in Australia over the age of 16 do not pay tax. The personal tax cuts in this bill continue the government's commitment to ongoing structural tax reforms. They increase the rewards for those who wish to work overtime, seek promotion or acquire skills. They strengthen the international competitiveness of the tax system.

This is an important bill that gives effect to budget measures. It again demonstrates that this is the government that cuts taxes for the Australian public. This government can achieve this result because of its very sound management of the Australian economy, which has made the Australian economy one of the great growth economies in the world. I commend the bill to the Senate.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: —The chamber has before it sheet 4242, which has just been circulated but which we have just pre-announced. It is not rocket science to understand what the amendments seek to do. I did cover the matters fully in my speech on the second reading and I will address those briefly. I seek leave to move Democrat amendments (1) and (2) together.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

quote.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (line 7), omit table item 1, substitute:

entry.para: (a) for the 2004-05 year of income—exceeds $7,500 but does not exceed $21,600; and(b) for later years of income—exceeds $9,000 but does not exceed $21,600

quote.para: (2) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3, omit items 2, 3 and 4.

speech.para: The Democrats also oppose schedule 1 in the following terms:

quote.para: (3) Schedule 1, item 2, page 3 (line 8) to page 4 (before line 1). TO BE OPPOSED.

speech.para: Obviously, the government will not support this proposal because they are going to go for their own package, which is quite understandable. This proposal of ours is designed to raise the tax-free threshold in two tranches in the first income year from $6,000 to $7,500 and in the second year to $9,000. It is a policy of ours that we have been promoting for several years. We do think that this would enable everyone—all nine million Australian taxpayers—to get a tax cut instead of just the top 20 per cent, and of course it will proportionately have a much greater effect for low-income earners, which is where we think the priority for tax cuts needs to commence. As I made very clear in my speech on the second reading, we do not consider higher income Australians earning above $52,000 and below $100,000 to be rich. That would be an unreasonable attitude. This proposal simply reflects our perspective that we should start by producing greater tax equity and improving the disposable income possibilities for lower income people, and we think the tax-free threshold is the simplest and easiest way to commence that process.

talk.start.para: —I indicate on behalf of the Labor Party, as I indicated in my speech on the second reading, that we will be supporting the government's tax cuts and that we will be bringing forward our own package. I am sure that when the Democrats see our package they will be very supportive. I am confident it is a package that will deliver broader and fairer tax cuts to all Australians. We believe that it will deserve the Democrats support in the future, and I look forward to Senator Murray's endorsement of our tax package when I put it on the table.

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Senator Murray is correct that the government is not disposed to support his proposals, but I do want to take a few minutes to say why. The amendment proposing to increase the tax-free threshold from $6,000 to $7,500 in 2004-05 and from $7,500 to $9,000 in 2005-06 would cost in the order of—and because of the time available to me we cannot be held to this—$6 billion. This would obviously affect the capacity of the government to fund essential community services. However, the government has given tax cuts to those who earn less than $52,000 as part of the new tax system.

speech.para: I want to make it perfectly clear and put it on the record that taxpayers and seniors at all income levels have benefited from a continuing program of tax reform. The personal tax cuts that were announced in the 2004-05 budget are the third stage in ongoing structural reform of the personal income tax system. I think Senator Kemp did mention that the combined effect of these three stages of tax reform has been to deliver significant tax cuts to all Australian taxpayers. Taxpayers earning $20,000 are paying around 23 per cent less in tax than prior to the new tax system; those on $50,000, around average weekly earnings, are paying around 21 per cent less tax than prior to the new tax system; and by 1 July 2005 taxpayers earning $90,000 will be paying 18 per cent less than prior to the new tax system. Most importantly, raising the top thresholds will ensure that those on average weekly earnings stay in the 30 per cent tax bracket, which I am sure is an objective that this chamber would support. More than 80 per cent of taxpayers will remain in the 30 per cent tax bracket or a lower tax bracket even after ongoing growth in wages over the next four years.

I remind the chamber that it is important to bear in mind that people who do not pay tax simply cannot benefit from the tax cuts. As Senator Kemp indicated a little earlier, the estimate is that there are around 6.8 million people aged 16 and over who do not pay tax and who could not possibly benefit from tax measures of the kind proposed. Maybe some would, but certainly if you do not pay tax it would be very difficult to imagine how you could. A single adult does not pay tax until their taxable income reaches $7,383, and this effective threshold would be higher if they receive an allowance or a pension. Of course pensions are now indexed so they are just not tied to the CPI. The majority of single adults and couples without children who do not gain from the 2004 budget package are not taxpayers. Obviously in another bill we will be debating the advantages of the superannuation co-contribution for low- to middle-income earners.

Families with children are receiving significant increases in family assistance under the changes announced in the budget through increases in the family tax benefit for lower and middle income families as well of course as a reduction in the taper rate at which family tax benefit is withdrawn. The estimate I have is that 99.8 per cent of families with dependent children under the age of 16 benefit from the 2004 budget package, as indeed they should—this government makes no apologies for putting families front and centre in the way in which it has.

As the Democrats would know, the government provides substantial tax relief for senior Australians through the senior Australian's tax offset, or SATO as it is colloquially called, at a cost of around $1.6 billion each year. Eligible single senior Australians can now earn up to $20,500 without paying any income tax or Medicare levy. While the offset phases out at a rate of 12.5c for each dollar of income over this amount, singles can earn up to $38,340 and still benefit from the offset. Couples can earn up to $33,612 without paying tax, depending on how much income each member of the couple earns, and still receive some offset at combined incomes of up to $59,244. As a result of these benefits many senior Australians need not even lodge a tax return.

Many senior Australians of course have shares, and anyone with shares might also benefit from the redesigned company tax arrangements where excess imputation credits are refundable. In the past imputation credits could only be used to offset a tax liability, which meant that obviously there were times when those credits were wasted. The government has also legislated the indexation of the aged pension, as I mentioned a moment ago, by the higher wages growth, male total average weekly earnings, or CPI—whichever is the highest. This indexation has led to significant real increases in pensions for aged pensioners, veterans and disability pensioners. Part rate pensioners continue to keep significantly more pension for every dollar of private income they receive above the income test-free areas as a result of the reduction in the pension withdrawal rate from 50 per cent to 40 per cent.

Having considered Senator Murray's proposals—and I do give very careful consideration to Senator Murray's suggestions because he does have a very deep interest in the tax system and from time to time does make suggestions that warrant consideration—at this stage and as part of the government's response to the budget, we will not be supporting them. They are not really something that is able to be contemplated in the context of a very large budget in which some tax cuts have been delivered for higher income earners simply as a matter of fairness and equity because they missed out when others got substantial tax cuts. But, as I have endeavoured to point out comprehensively, this government really has provided benefits across the whole income spectrum within the confines of a restructure of the tax system that has really seen nobody miss out, certainly not those earning less than $52,000. So it is for those reasons and for the fact that we have given further assistance to families through the family tax benefit, which is how we see it as being most efficacious for those families, particularly for ones that do not put in tax returns, the government will not be supporting these proposals.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Minister, for your very full response to our proposal. You would recognise, of course, that one of our purposes in moving such amendments is to flush out attitudes on these ideas. I note the slow striptease we are being subjected to by Labor, who will eventually announce where they are going in this area but not just yet. The only remark I want to add is that the chamber should recognise that these proposals are roughly revenue neutral because we propose to substitute one set of tax cut proposals for another.

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I would like to make a correction. Treasury's maths needed to be readjusted as I spoke and they now estimate that the revenue cost probably would be in the order of $4.5 billion, not the earlier figure, accruing in 2005-06 after the tax-free threshold increases to $9,000, not allowing for offsetting savings. Once again, that is not necessarily a firm figure but it is the best indication I can give you at the moment.

—I take this opportunity to make my general contribution to this debate. This bill rolls out the latest of this government's attacks on progressive taxation in this country. Last year we had the $4 a week hamburger and milkshake tax cuts, which cost us $2.4 billion last year and will cost us $10 billion over the next four years. That is the direct financial cost. The bill also cost us the opportunity to abolish higher education fees for university students and the opportunity to return to free tertiary education. It cost us the opportunity to invest in public housing, the opportunity to support the rebuilding of bulk-billing in this country and the opportunity to invest in a range of other vital public investments. The latest budget tax cut, through this piece of legislation, will cost us $1.9 billion this year and $14.7 billion over the next four years. That is $14.7 billion that the public have consistently told the government and the parliament they want to see invested in vital public services in this country.

speech.para: The government is keen to talk about giving back to taxpayers but does not say what the costs of these election handouts will be in the further neglect of our public services. This bill not only robs us of the opportunity this year to make more sustainable and responsible use of taxation revenue by investing in public works and public services but also it robs us of the opportunity to do it in the future. It does this because it has the effect of flattening the personal income tax scale, allowing those on higher incomes to pay less tax. This change in the income tax scales will, as the government knows, be electorally difficult for any opposition to change if they were to win government. This does not mean that they should not do it, and in fact the Greens believe they should do it. But it is likely in an electoral climate that this change may be with us for many years, with the result that future governments will have less revenue to cater to society's collective needs while the richest individuals will have more money to cater to their personal wants.

I simply do not understand anyone thinking that this system could possibly be fair. The Greens cannot understand why such a system could be described by the government as being fair: it gives more money to the wealthy and it is not fair to the collective benefit of the rest of the country. The Greens reject this approach. We will oppose this piece of legislation, as we opposed the tax cuts in the last budget. We are ardent supporters of a progressive taxation system. We see it as a tool to deliver economic and social justice through the redistribution of personal wealth into public wealth. We believe in investing in public services rather than investing in tax cuts.

The bill does the opposite. Over the next four years this bill will deliver more than $14 million into the pockets of some of the wealthiest people in our society. It comes at a time when our public school teachers are taking industrial action in response to the continuing relative erosion of their salaries, which has seen them fall by one-third since 1972, relative to average weekly earnings. We are seeing house prices skyrocketing and private rents following, while the Commonwealth is stepping back from its role in providing public housing through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Bulk-billing rates are at their lowest level ever, yet the government is choosing not to invest this surplus taxpayers' money into our public health system.

Our natural environment and our infrastructure are in dire need of protection and expansion, not the green-tinged announcements such as those being made by the Prime Minister in the Great Hall at the moment, which in fact give more money to companies like Rio Tinto for their geosequestration and other research in the fossil fuel areas. The announcement today about the environment and announcements in recent weeks about the infrastructure in Australia have been woefully inadequate. This inadequacy is a result of both a terminal lack of vision by this government and a lack of real understanding about the central importance of the environment to the future of all of us. This inadequacy also shows an unwillingness by the government to invest public money in our public future—that is, in our public hospitals, our public schools and our future environment through our natural heritage.

The Greens have announced and supported a green bonds initiative that would see the government issuing bonds to raise $35 billion over the next 10 years. This is quite a conservative amount of money to invest in public and environmental infrastructure, but it is needed if we are to have any significant impact on the environmental fortunes of this country as we go through the 21st century. A raft of community figures are also calling for investment in environmentally sustainable infrastructure. I attended the Press Club address by the ACTU secretary, Greg Combet, who called for increased public debt in order to invest in our public infrastructure. I note the remarks of the Chief Executive of the Australian Industry Group, Heather Ridout, who said:

quote.para: ... we have a deficit fetish in Australia which is really disguising under-investment in a lot of our major infrastructure assets and it's really encouraging government, not sufficiently, to invest in long-term assets for the country.

speech.para: But the government is not listening, despite what the Prime Minister may say. Of course, the urgent investment needs do not end with the environment. The Greens have spoken many times in this chamber about the importance of investing in public health and public education. We have identified the need for in the order of $4 billion in additional annual investment in Medicare, which could be funded by abolishing the private health insurance rebate—taxpayers' money that provides insurance, not health services. We have also identified the need for $7 billion in public education spending across the lifelong spectrum of education, from preschool through to university and TAFE tertiary education.

My office has been inundated, as I hope many senators' offices have been, with information on the resource needs of our public schools. I take this opportunity to seek leave to table a raft of representations from public school teachers, which have been circulated to all parties, identifying the resources needed for their public schools. They were faxed to senators' offices, but I am happy to provide the government with a copy now.

talk.start.para: —There was a request from the Greens to table documents, but the Greens are advised that the government have not yet read the documents and cannot agree to the tabling until those documents have been read by the whips.

—They have been provided to the minister on duty. There is an opportunity during the rest of my contribution to peruse those documents and to determine whether I may be granted leave at the end of my contribution.

speech.para: We should be investing in the needs of these public schools, as they have been outlined. They include things such as toilet blocks and new readers books in schools. They call for investment in public resources rather than in the tax cuts proposed in this legislation. When our schools are going without these things, it is not the time to pay bonuses to the already well-off, but that is not the way the Treasurer sees it. The Treasurer would have us believe that this piece of legislation is simply about returning money that has already been taken away as a result of the government's favourite bugbear—bracket creep. We have heard numerous members of the government claim that the top tax rates are far lower in the income scale than they used to be and that a move to reduce this burden on high-income earners is long overdue. This is deliberately misleading rubbish.

Professor John Quiggin, from the Australian National University, has been at pains to point out this deception. In the Australian Financial Review just a few weeks ago, he described this claim as `one of the sillier claims in the debate over tax policy'. This is because the range of the tax scale was more progressive back in the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s. In that period, those paying the top rate of tax paid up to 67c in the dollar; those now paying the top rate pay 48c in the dollar and earn about the same amount relative to those who paid 48c in the dollar during earlier decades. So the idea that there has been some terribly unjust shift in taxation rates for those earning 1.3 times the average weekly earnings is simply and plainly wrong.

The reason the government wants to bring in this tax cut is not that injustices have been done unto higher income earners. It is much more to do with how those higher income earners, or those aspiring to become high-income earners, will vote in the coming election. If the government were responsible in amending the tax laws it would look at the $8.2 billion in loopholes that the Australian Council of Social Services has identified, such as diverting income to a private company or lower tax rates payable, equalling $1.3 billion; executive perks such as salary sacrificing for a company car, coming up to $1 billion; income splitting to reduce tax payable, coming up to $800 million; family trusts in the order of $400 million and salary sacrificing superannuation in the order of $2.5 billion. These are the kinds of measures that the average Josephine wants to hear about, because this is what progressive taxation is supposed to be—tax according to one's ability to pay rather than tax according to one's ability to evade.

On the other end of the scale, low-income earners need to be relieved of the massive impact of high marginal tax rates when they move from welfare to work. The GST is an example of the regressive taxation brought in by this government that has hurt low-income earners the most. The Greens support the rolling back of this GST. Ordinary Australians are being rorted and services are being run down. Their incomes have declined in comparison to those at the top of the ladder. As long as they do not live in marginal seats—and most of them do not—this government looks set to continue ignoring them. The Greens say no to this insulting, cynical logic of election handouts and the haemorrhaging of our desperately needed public funds into the pockets of the wealthy. The Greens will oppose this legislation. During the second reading debate I sought to move a second reading amendment, which I will read out for the Senate:

quote.para: ... condemning the government for attacking the progressive nature of personal income tax system, reaffirming the importance of personal income tax system as a means of both redistributing wealth and providing for adequate public services and supporting alternative measures that would redirect the revenue forgone through this measure and other regressive budget measures into public health, public education, housing and environmental protection.

speech.para: The Australian Greens will support the amendments proposed by Senator Murray as an improvement on the current piece of legislation, which we will oppose. I seek leave to table the statements from public school teachers on the resources they would like to see public money spent on in their schools.

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I have only just had a quick look at the documents. Whilst the government would normally be disposed to allow any document to be tabled that is remotely relevant to a bill, flicking through this it appears to be multiple copies of a petition that relates to some requests for further facilities in the public-private education debate. Even if money were not available pursuant to these tax cuts, it is not customary to hypothecate on any amount saved on one bill for some other purpose. For those reasons, leave is not granted.

—I am surprised by this move by the minister. My understanding is that, where people have written petitions that are not in a format that can be tabled as a petition in parliament, it is customary to seek leave—as I have done many times in similar instances—to table those documents or those letters from individuals about their areas of concern. The legislation we are debating right now is about government priorities on how budget money is to be spent. Last year I moved an amendment on behalf of the Australian Greens to say that this money should be spent on public education. That is the same discussion that I have just had in putting forward the Greens contribution to this debate. It fits perfectly with the contributions that we have had from public school teachers and parents around the country who want to ensure that their voices can be heard in this debate. They are saying, `Rather than having the money put into tax cuts, we would like to see it put into our public schools.'

speech.para: I have sought leave many times in the parliament to table contributions when they have not been in petition form. All the other parties have granted leave for these documents to be tabled. They were provided to the government so that they could peruse them before my asking leave for them to be tabled in the parliament. I ask the minister to reconsider her decision to ensure that the concerns of these teachers about how public money should be spent in the context of the budget outlined in the bill we are debating today are tabled.

talk.start.para: (Senator Kirk)—Senator Nettle, leave is not granted.

—I urge Senator Coonan to reconsider this matter. It is not an unreasonable thing that Senator Nettle is seeking. Perhaps you are being a little over officious. It is hardly an offensive set of documents. For example, the Tuggeranong Primary School talks about the different things that it needs money for—covered walkways, more teachers, new classrooms, a new toilet block, a technology room, airconditioned classrooms, playground seating, drainage fixed, new basketball backboards, refurbish old classrooms, school fencing and three computers in each room. That is not an unreasonable petition for Senator Nettle to seek leave to table. I can only urge you, Senator Coonan, to possibly reconsider. I think it is not an unreasonable petition.

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Senator Conroy, as you know, I usually find requests from you to be close to irresistible. The difficulty I have with this bundle—and I would never seek to be officious with Senator Nettle or anyone else—is that it is very large. The first five documents seem to be exactly the same. I do not know whether they are duplicates. It would have been helpful if we had had them a little earlier. I would like to have an opportunity to at least look at them properly.
—I might take up the offer from the minister to seek leave for the documents to be tabled later.

speech.para: Question put:

motion.para: That the amendments (Senator Murray's) be agreed to.

talk.start.para: —The question now is that schedule 1, item 2 stand as printed.

interjection.para: Question agreed to.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Senator COONAN (New South Wales—Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer) (1.58 p.m.)—I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

talker.name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
Senator BARTLETT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —It is necessary for the Australian Democrats to indicate that we have attempted to amend the Tax Laws Amendment (Personal Income Tax Reduction) Bill 2004. We have tried to amend the magnitude of the bill, which has an enormous amount of public expenditure involved, to make it fair and spread the income tax relief equitably—including to low-income earners and the poor—but that attempt has not been successful. We now have a bill that pours billions of dollars into the pockets of the highest income earners. Once again, the Labor Party stood up to say it does not oppose the bill while condemning the government for what they are doing. The Australian public will be stuck with this unfair measure, regardless of what happens at the election. If the government is returned, then this unfair measure will be in place. It is simply another case, in our view, of exclusive tax cuts for high-income earners.

speech.para: Debate interrupted.

talker.name: Faulkner, Sen John
Senator FAULKNER
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, Minister for Defence and Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the minister aware of the letter sent to the Red Cross by the commanding officer of Abu Ghraib prison, Brigadier General Karpinski—a letter which Defence confirmed was drafted by Australian legal officer Major O'Kane? Does the Howard government agree with the proposition contained in that letter that prisoners will not be treated according to Geneva convention standards where `absolute military security requires it'? In the Howard government's view, when does `absolute military security' operate to deprive certain classes of prisoners in Iraq of basic standards of treatment? Did any of the Australian military lawyers posted to Iraq give advice or make representations to our coalition partners that all prisoners in Iraq should be treated in accordance with the Geneva conventions?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —I do not think that you can opt out of the Geneva conventions, and Australia would not seek to opt out. I do not think you have a choice—you have to comply with the provisions of the convention. One, of course, relates to prisoners of war and the other relates to civilians that might be taken and held. The position of the Australian government is as I have just stated. If somebody is being held other than under a Geneva convention, then it would be the attitude of the Australian government that basic humanitarian standards should nevertheless prevail. I am sure that that would be the legal advice the Australian government would receive as well.

—Mr President, I note that the minister did not answer my original question. Just to be clear, Minister, let me ask you this supplementary question: what steps have been taken to investigate whether the 100-plus prisoners physically captured by Australian troops have been treated according to the standards of the Geneva convention? Have you made any efforts at all to find out about the fate of these prisoners, including where they were ultimately detained and precisely what treatment they experienced?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —Australia did not capture and detain prisoners. In the instance that Australia was involved in the capture of prisoners, they were detained by the United States. The US, of course, is a party to the Geneva conventions, and Australia has every confidence that the US would comply with the obligations that it has accepted.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Ian Macdonald. Will the minister inform the Senate of the benefits to the environment from the Howard government's energy initiatives? Is the minister aware of any alternative approaches?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Payne for that question. I know that Senator Payne is proud to be a member of a government that not only has a fine record of environmental activism but also has an environmental vision for the future. Building on initiatives like the Natural Heritage Trust, the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality, the representative areas program for the Great Barrier Reef, the marine protected areas in Australia's vast territorial oceans, meeting its Kyoto targets, the Living Murray initiative, the national water initiative and the Greenhouse Challenge—just to name a few—today's energy statement demonstrates irrefutably that this government is the greenest government in the history of the Federation.

answer.para: Those who are serious about these issues should study the coalition's environmental agenda and our record and compare them with the promises, perceptions and stunts of other political parties. The Prime Minister's energy statement, delivered just an hour ago, provides real leadership and vision. It highlighted the establishment of a $500 million fund to bring at least $1 billion of extra new investment in low-emission technologies. It also highlighted $134 million to support commercialisation of renewable technologies and $75 million for solar cities trials to demonstrate a visionary energy scenario where solar energy efficiency and market reforms combine to provide a sustainable future. Also, the statement highlighted the requirement that Australia's largest energy users undertake regular energy efficiency assessments.

The ability to spend money on the environmental enhancements that have been mentioned today follows on from the Howard government's historically good management of the Australian economy. You cannot invest in our natural heritage and in leading edge emissions technology to help the environment if you have the sort of banana republic style economy left to us by the last Labor government. The Howard government is looking to the future and acting to lower the costs of meeting future greenhouse constraints. This will position Australia well to contribute to global emissions reductions whilst maintaining our nation's prosperity.

By contrast, Labor's proposals seem to stop at parachuting in—in a less than democratic way, I might add—some wealthy, non-voting rock star or resorting to stunts about Tasmanian forests, and a proposal for the Murray-Darling system that is less than what the Commonwealth and the state Labor governments have already agreed upon. Labor's determination to sign the flawed Kyoto protocol will bring not one improvement in the world's climate change problem but it will cost thousands of jobs in regional Australia. It will cost economic growth and it will cost export income. Labor's mandatory renewable energy target of five per cent would cost Australia something like $11 billion. If you look at the proposal of that other stunt party, the Greens, of 10 per cent, you would see that would cost Australia something like $23 billion annually. It cannot be done. This is the party and the government that is serious about the environment. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —What a loser!
—Order! Senator Brown, that was uncalled for.
—My question is to Senator Ellison, the Minister for Justice and Customs. I ask the minister whether he recalls his comments in his doorstop interview yesterday when he stated:

quote.para: Certainly there have been allegations that the integrity of the Australian Crime Commission has been compromised by two state policemen and as a result of that we're carrying out an independent investigation in conjunction with the commonwealth ombudsman.

The report from that investigation will be to hand very shortly—I envisage in the next fortnight—but I am confident that there is no evidence of systemic corruption in the Australian Crime Commission.

question.para: Given that the investigation has not yet concluded and that the report will not be handed down for two weeks, how can the minister be confident that there is no evidence of systemic corruption in the Australian Crime Commission? By pre-empting the findings of the uncompleted investigation, haven't the minister's comments, as well as making public comment on an ongoing operational matter, compromised the independence of the investigation?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —I have been asked two questions. One question relates to my own beliefs in relation to the Australian Crime Commission, in which I have confidence, and the other one relates to the two specific detectives concerned, one of whom comes from New South Wales and one from Victoria, both of whom were secondees to the Australian Crime Commission. The Australian Crime Commission comprises two-thirds its own staff and one-third secondees. I have been asked questions about the activities of the two particular officers that I have mentioned. In regard to that question, I have said that there has been an independent investigation carried out, the results of which are reportedly due soon to the Commonwealth Ombudsman, within the fortnight. I look forward to the receipt of that report. What has been investigated are the activities of these two particular officers and the circumstances surrounding their alleged corrupt activities.

answer.para: Of my own confidence in the Australian Crime Commission I can say this: no evidence has been produced to the government which would indicate systemic corruption in the Australian Crime Commission. The Four Corners program last night centred around the activities of two particular officers. I have yet to receive from anyone evidence which would indicate systemic corruption. But I have said that the Commonwealth government regards these allegations concerning these two particular officers very seriously, and that is why we are paying such close attention to the investigation of these officers. In relation to the Australia Crime Commission itself, there is no police force in Australia which has the level of scrutiny that that body has. For instance, we have an intergovernmental committee of police ministers from across the country. They will be meeting at the end of this month. We have, as well as that, a board made up of police commissioners from around Australia: the head of Customs, the head of ASIO, the head of ASIC—the corporate regulator—and the Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department of the Commonwealth government. We also have a parliamentary joint committee on which members opposite preside over or participate in. In addition, we have the Commonwealth Ombudsman, who has oversight of the activities of the Australian Crime Commission.

The secondees have another layer of scrutiny—that is, their own disciplinary provisions in their home police force. The two particular police officers are subject to investigation. The disciplinary bodies in the states of Victoria and New South Wales are involved as well in the investigation into the officers' activities. I was not pre-empting the outcome of this independent investigation. What I was indicating was that there has been no evidence which would reveal systemic corruption in the Australian Crime Commission. To compare the Australian Crime Commission with the situation in Victoria is simply drawing a very long bow and, in fact, it is incorrect. The Four Corners program last night stated that there were over 100 allegations of corruption in relation to the Victoria Police.

Last night in the same program, two state police detectives who were seconded to the Australian Crime Commission were mentioned. It was stated in the same program that over 20-odd years there had been very few allegations of corruption concerning the Australian Crime Commission's predecessor, the NCA. In putting the Australian Crime Commission in place, we put in enhanced provisions in relation to accountability, professional standards, vetting and the turnover of staff so that we would not have entrenched practices growing up in that body. Forty-five per cent of its staff are new staff. This is a new body and one which is making a great contribution to law enforcement of this country. Having said that, we remain concerned about the allegations in relation to the two particular police officers, and we look forward to the early receipt of that independent investigation report, which I have mentioned.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the minister made an assessment of the Commonwealth Ombudsman's powers to ensure that the Ombudsman has sufficient power to investigate allegations of corruption involving officers serving with the Australian Crime Commission? Can the minister now assure the Senate that the Commonwealth Ombudsman has all the necessary powers to undertake such investigations and, if not, will he describe to the Senate what extra powers the Ombudsman will be granted?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —The Commonwealth Ombudsman has a similar power in relation to the Australian Crime Commission as he has in relation to the Australian Federal Police. That includes not only acting upon complaints brought to the Ombudsman but self-initiating an inquiry as well. I have mentioned, on the record, the number of inquiries which have been self-initiated by the Commonwealth Ombudsman. It was only recently that the state of Victoria saw fit to do that with its own ombudsman relating to his oversight of the police force in Victoria.

answer.para: The regime which has been in place for the Australian Federal Police has operated well. We looked at that when we set up the Australian Crime Commission, and we have a similar provision in relation to the Ombudsman in his oversight of the Australian Crime Commission. That was the subject of debate and the purview of the parliamentary joint committee when we set up the Australian Crime Commission at the beginning of last year. In addition to that, we have said we will do a comprehensive review of the Australian Crime Commission at the end of next year. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services. Will the minister inform the Senate how the Howard government is supporting Australian families through greater financial assistance as a result of good economic management? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Fifield for his question. I know that he knows, like all of us on this side know, that one of the best ways we can help Australian families and their children into the future is to have a strong economy. Last week Minister Andrews announced that Australia's unemployment rate was 5.5 per cent—the lowest level in almost 23 years. The unemployment rate is below six per cent, interest rates are below six per cent and inflation is below three per cent. Economic management is not a fluke and it is no accident.
