It requires a steady hand on the tiller—a steady hand on the budget. In net terms, we reduced the debt of $96 billion that Labor left us by almost $70 billion, saving us almost $6 billion in interest. We can assist families because we have made those savings. We are not paying interest on debt, racking up debt that we cannot afford or racking up debt for the next generation.

answer.para: The recent federal budget is designed to keep our economy strong. It is about securing our future. It is about supporting the backbone of Australian society—Australian families. It is about giving families choice and about giving them opportunities. The new More Help for Families measure will provide an additional $19.2 billion for families over five years. It is the largest package of assistance ever put in place by an Australian government. Around two million families with 3.5 million children will benefit from the changes to the family tax benefits system.

This week we continue to deliver to families. The one-off payment will see over the next two weeks about two million eligible families receiving a $600 payment for each dependent child. About two million families will start receiving an average payment of $1,200 in their bank accounts from this week. An eligible family with four children will receive $2,400. The bonus is tax free, and it is not taken into account in assessing pensions or benefits as income. It is expected that the majority of payments will have been made by 22 June and a smaller number by the end of June. Strong economic growth and good economic management by the Howard government have allowed us to deliver the extra financial support that families deserve.

Senator Fifield asked me about alternative policies. I really do not know that I can answer that question, Senator Fifield, because you get mixed messages. Mr Latham, on the 7.30 Report when he was asked to make a commitment that families would not be worse off under Labor, twice failed to give Australian families that commitment. Mr McMullan, the spokesperson for finance, when he was asked about the $600 supplement and the increase in the base rate of the family tax benefits, said that he could not guarantee that past 2005. So there is no policy. What Labor have been saying is, `After the budget, we'll tell you about the family policy.' It is nearly a month since the budget and we still have not got a family tax policy from the Labor Party—no policy, no sign of policy, no commitment to families that they will not be worse off and no guarantee that the $600 supplement will be continued past next financial year. There are no policies. Labor are a policy-free zone. They have had a chance. The budget has been there. When are the Labor Party going to give Australians information about their policy on families?

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Patterson, as Minister for Family and Community Services. Can the minister explain why the government has amended the indexation formula applying to the family tax benefit—a change that was not clearly disclosed in the explanatory memorandum of the family assistance legislation amendment? Isn't the reason the government refused to spell out this change to the indexation of family payments that it is designed to claw back the real value of the additional payments made in the budget?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer is no. I have said in a press release I put out that the government will take whatever action is necessary to deliver on its commitment that families receive $600 per child and that the real value of this payment is maintained in the future. But it gives me the opportunity to say again what we have done as a result of good economic management. It gives me the opportunity to say that families who are eligible for family tax benefit A will get a one-off payment of $600 per child into their bank accounts in the next two weeks. They will also get an increase of $600 per child in the family tax benefit A base rate.

—Senator Collins shouts and interjects because she does not want to hear this because they have not got a policy. She does not want to hear that families will be better off on average by about $1,200 per child this financial year as a result of good economic management and as a result of giving a social dividend back to families because we have been able to run the budget in a way that is not racking up debt like the Labor Party was doing. We have said that the supplement will be indexed to CPI. We will look and we will make sure—and I have made a commitment—that families will receive $600 per child and the real value of this payment will be maintained in the future. Mr McMullan has said that he cannot guarantee that after the 2004-05 financial year that $600 will be there. Mr Latham, when he had two opportunities on the 7.30 Report to say families would not be worse off under Labor, failed to give Australian families that guarantee.
—What about your opportunities last week that we're still waiting for? What about your opportunities?
—Senator Collins, you have asked your question.

—Mr Latham failed to give Australians that guarantee. The Labor Party do not want to hear this. They do not want to know that they are giving mixed messages to the community about what their family policy is. Mr McMullan says that after the 2004-05 financial year they cannot guarantee the $600. Mr Latham said he will not guarantee that families will not be worse off. We have said that families are getting $600 per child into their bank account in the next two weeks if they are eligible for FTB A during this year and the family tax benefit rate will be increased by $600 and we will maintain the real value of that $600 increase.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. For the benefit of the Senate, can the minister confirm that her departmental head refused to provide a guarantee that the government's unexplained change to the indexation of family tax benefit would not lead to the clawback of the additional payments made in the budget? Minister, why will you not come clean about your planned post-election clawback of these additional family payments?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —This gives me the opportunity again to remind families that they will get $600 per child, if they have been eligible for FTB A this financial year, in their bank accounts now; that the base rate of family tax benefit will increase by $600; and that we will maintain the real value of that. We have made a commitment to that; it will not be clawed back. Senator Collins, I have said that we will maintain the real value of the $600 payment. We have given families $1,200 this financial year if they have been eligible all year for family tax benefit A—per child: $600 in the one-off payment and $600 increase in the base rate. We have done that in this financial year and we will do that in every other financial year. Mr McMullan, the finance spokesman, will not even guarantee that that will continue past the 2004-05 financial year. Mr Latham has failed to convince families that they will not be worse off under Labor.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing. Can the minister confirm Minister Abbott's remarks at the weekend that he will make emergency contraception a prescription only drug? How and when will this be put into effect?

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator IAN CAMPBELL
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —That is a question I will refer to the minister. I saw his reported comments, and he can respond.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing has indicated that he saw the remarks. I would have thought it would have been useful for him to come prepared to question time with answers. However, I will ask some further questions while we are at it. Is it not the case that, in fact, the minister has no powers to reverse the National Drugs and Poisons Schedule Committee's decision and that that is a matter for the states and New Zealand? How is it that the minister made such a serious blunder? Is it not the case that there is, in fact, no evidence to suggest that emergency contraception has encouraged teenage sexual activity? Minister, how many unwanted pregnancies could be expected from denying women early access to this contraception? How many women will not be able to get an appointment with a GP to get a prescription within the required 72 hours of unprotected sex? Does the minister agree that sex education is important in preventing both unwanted and teenage pregnancies? If so, why is it not being proposed instead of taking Australian women back to the last century in having no choice over their own reproduction? (Time expired)

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator IAN CAMPBELL
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —I am happy to answer questions on policy, but the senator has asked me to pass a running commentary on what the minister for health has said. I do not think I need to be a commentator. There are plenty of other highly paid people out there who can commentate on what he has said. What the minister has said on the policy issue of the availability of Postinor-2 is that he wants to have a look at it. He has had serious concerns raised with him. As a diligent minister for health who has delivered significant reforms to the delivery of health in Australia, such as greater access to GPs—and who thoroughly supports, for example, the 30 per cent rebate for private health insurance, which is threatened by the Democrats and Labor—he is looking into a very important issue that affects the health of many thousands of Australians.

—My question is directed to Senator Patterson, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Can the minister confirm that the head of her department gave an explicit undertaking on 4 June to provide answers to questions from the Labor Party senators about the government's unexplained changes to the indexation of family payments? Can the minister explain why those answers, which were promised would be available by close of business last Friday, have been withheld from the committee? Did the minister intervene to prevent the answers being released?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Senator Forshaw most probably would not understand that, when you give $19.2 billion of assistance to families and when you give a one-off payment of $600 per child to families, it requires enormous systems changes. Also, giving an additional $600 in the base rate, as we paid in September, to eligible families, requires enormous systems changes. The department is under enormous pressure in that area. Mr Sullivan said in the estimates:

quote.para: We will commit to answer those as soon as possible and hopefully by the end of next week.

answer.para: He emphasised `hopefully by the end of next week' because he did not know how many questions there would be. We thought there was going to be one question; there were a number of questions. The department has been working on those questions during the week. Mr Sullivan said `we will commit to answer those as soon as possible and hopefully by the end of next week'. The department is working day and night on ensuring that families get their $600 per child lump sum if they have been eligible for FTB A. They are working day and night—and I thank them for that—to ensure that this financial year families get their additional base increase of $600 per child in family tax benefit A. They are doing their level best to answer those questions, and we will get them to the committee as soon as possible. Mr Sullivan said he hoped that it would be by the end of the week. It was not by the end of the week. We will get them to the committee as soon as possible.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister give a guarantee here today to the Senate that she will immediately release to the Senate committee her department's explanations for why the family payment indexation formula has been changed? Minister, if there is no clawback, why should there be any need for legislative amendments, as outlined in your press release of 6 June?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —We have guaranteed that the family tax benefit supplement will be increased in real terms and maintained. Answers will be given to the committee as soon as they are ready. As I have said, the department is under enormous pressure to deliver the $600 per child lump sum that will go into families' bank accounts—that is, the largest assistance to families ever. Also, it will be working on the increase in the base rate of $600 per child in family tax benefit A that will be available. That is an increase Labor has failed to guarantee. Mr Latham has failed to say that families will not be worse off under Labor. Also, Mr McMullan has said that he is not sure that that benefit will be there after 2004-05. We have guaranteed that increase and we have guaranteed that it will be maintained in real terms.

—My question is to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's energy statement that was delivered today. Why does the government believe that we are still only at the demonstration stage for renewable technologies? Surely we have a solid foundation now, with the growing use of wind and solar, so why go back to just pilot programs? Why are there few, if any, incentives in the package for the actual take-up and use of renewable alternatives on a national scale? Basically, why is there no increase in MRET? The Prime Minister mentioned risk. What is he talking about? How will our economy suffer, as he claims? What are the substantial costs that he mentioned in his speech at the launch? What is the modelling or other evidence that you have that shows that there is a risk if we increase MRET by a modest amount?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Australian government is committed to a sustainable future, and the statement put out by the Prime Minister today is very much consistent with that principle. It is a statement that indicates, not surprisingly, that the government is determined to maintain economic growth in this country and to take advantage of the comparative benefits that we have in our natural resource sector but nevertheless to exploit those in an energy efficient way. The government has in place existing programs and existing incentives for renewable energy that encourage that, but also it believes that there is the potential for new technologies to greatly assist in the overall task of a more energy efficient economy and that there is a strong case in favour of investing public money, together with private sector money, in the development of these new technologies.

answer.para: Therefore, the Prime Minister indicated that included in the range of new initiatives is the fact that the government would be driving investment of at least $1.5 billion to demonstrate breakthrough technologies with significant long-term greenhouse gas reduction potential through the establishment of a $500 million fund to leverage private sector investment of at least $1 billion in the demonstration of low-emission technologies. What the Prime Minister is saying is, yes, there are renewable technologies available, they are being taken up in Australia and we do have a program that encourages and supports the taking up of those technologies. It would have been possible as one alternative to extend that program but there are alternative ways to go forward. In the view of the government, investment in this major fund to encourage the development of other alternative energy efficient opportunities would be a significant national investment.

I would respectfully suggest to the honourable senator that it is possible to have it both ways. If Australia is to develop the energy efficient economy that it desires, it is important to go along both paths. It is important on the one hand to support the existing programs, which we see are being implemented at the moment, and on the other hand to seek out new alternatives, of which there are obviously many, and to support them not only at the research phase but also at the demonstration phase in order that they might become commercially efficient, be taken up and contribute to that very important goal of a sustainable economy.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, why will the economy not be stable or able to grow if we increase MRET by a modest amount? You mentioned, and I thank you for doing so, that what is being done currently is working. Yes, MRET is working, so why not build on it? It will stall in a couple of years, as the capacity will be filled, if we do not increase the target. Can't we have it both ways by putting in place your proposals but also by lifting the target for the generation of electricity by renewable industries such as solar and wind? Is the government aware that a report by the Allen Consulting Group entitled Sustainable energy: economic dimensions says that we can significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions and boost the wind and solar industries together if we increase the target to a modest 3½ per cent, that there would be absolutely no negative impact on our economy and that, in fact, jobs would increase?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The issue is how you break up the funding that you can afford. As I said, the Prime Minister has agreed that $500 million will go in to leverage private sector investment in the demonstration of low emission technologies, $134 million will go to support commercialisation of renewable technologies and a commitment of $75 million will go into solar cities trials to demonstrate a visionary new energy scenario, where solar, energy efficiency and market reforms will combine to provide a sustainable future. In some ways the government is covering the field. It is doing so, as I said, because it wishes to achieve a more sustainable economy. That is in Australia's national interest. It is in not only its short-term interest but also the interests of future generations. The government has put a lot of effort into this program and has invested a large sum of public money because it believes it is so important. It is easy to quarrel about the balance, but this is money that will be well spent in Australia's interest. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Patterson, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Can the minister confirm whether the government's $20 million national advertising campaign to explain its budget family payment measures will include information about the risk of family payment debts, which about one-third of all families—around 600,000 households—get each year? Minister, will your pre-election advertising blitz inform families of the likelihood that they will need to use the budget payment to offset these debts because you have failed to fix the problem in the system?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Every time Labor gets up and asks me a question it gives me an opportunity to remind Australians about the $19.2 billion in additional assistance we are giving to families—the largest assistance to families in the history of Australia. A one-off $600 payment to families who are eligible for FTB A during this year, for each child, will be going into their bank accounts in the next two weeks. That is an amazing amount of money, coming as a result of a social dividend because we have run the economy in a way that has enabled us to give families the support they need. We are increasing the family tax benefit each year by $600 per child, indexed in real terms. That is an increase that Mr McMullan has said he cannot guarantee after the next financial year. I hope the Labor Party will be telling people that loud and clear, because that seems to be Labor's policy.

answer.para: It seems that Mr Latham's policy seems to be that he cannot actually tell Australian families whether they will be worse off under Labor. The information campaign is about ensuring that families understand their benefits and their entitlements: $600 per child in their bank accounts if they were eligible for FTB A—on average, $1,200 per family. We want them to make sure they check their bank accounts. There are a small number of families who will receive it by cheque and a small number of families who will need to make sure that they get their entitlement.

We will be increasing the base rate of family tax benefit by $600 over the financial year. That will be reconciled at the end of the financial year. If people have received that $600 per child during the year because they have not been able to estimate their income accurately, that will be taken into account. We have reduced the number of people who get an overpayment, we have increased the number of people who get their entitlement correct and we have given families top-ups, which Labor has failed to do and has failed to guarantee they will do in the future. We are going to ensure that families understand that they will get $19.2 billion more in the forward estimates and that they will get on average about $7,000 per family in family tax benefit in addition to other support that they are being given.

By this measure alone they will get $600 per child in their bank accounts in the next two weeks, and they will get an increase in the maximum rate of family tax benefit A. We need to make sure that Australian families understand that. We need to make sure that they get their entitlement. We are working to ensure that they get their estimates of their income as accurate as possible. We will make sure that families in similar circumstances are treated in a similar way and given similar assistance from the taxpayer over a financial year.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm whether the government's same $2 million pre-election advertising blitz will explain to families lodging their tax return before September that their family payment debt will not be stripped this year? Will the advertising explain that their likely $900 debt will be offset against their $600 payment in September, in an attempt to disguise the fact that the system has not yet been fixed?

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —What we will be doing is making sure that families understand that over a financial year their benefit will increase by $600 per child per eligible family. That is what we will be making sure they are aware of. When families got an underpayment when Labor was in government, Labor did not top it up. What we are about is ensuring that families in similar circumstances, with a similar number of children and a similar income, receive similar assistance from the taxpayer over a financial year. That is what we will making sure families understand. We will be making sure that they inform Centrelink about changes. One of the other things we will do, when a secondary income earner returns to work after the birth of a child, is quarantine the fact that they may have had more tax benefit than they were entitled to in that first part of the year, to ensure that we reduce overpayments. We have taken a number of measures, including the More Choices for Families, which more families are taking up to reduce the likelihood of an overpayment. We will be increasing payments to families by $600 per child, per year. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, Senator Ian Campbell. Will the minister inform the Senate of the investment the government is making to ensure that Australia's road and rail systems are able to meet the long-term transport challenges facing the nation? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies that would jeopardise the government's long-term plan?

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
Senator IAN CAMPBELL
talker.role: Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator McGauran for asking an important question for Australia, particularly for regional and rural Australia and for Victoria. Victoria was the big winner in terms of increase in road construction from the AusLink announcement. Many coalition senators will remember the Roads to Recovery announcement that was made about three years ago—a $1.2 billion injection that particularly helped rural and regional roads and local councils to build local roads. We had the Labor Party then calling it a `boondoggle'. That is what Mr Beazley called it. Luckily, not many people knew what a boondoggle was, but Mr Beazley did. And what did we get last Monday when the Deputy Prime Minister and I announced the AusLink program, the biggest increase in road construction spending in Australian history? They decided to call it a `pork barrel' this time. This is the Labor Party's commitment to road funding. We announced a historic increase in road funding three years ago and it is called a `boondoggle'; this year it is called a `pork barrel'. We look forward at some stage to the Labor Party coming up with their own roads policy. At the moment they are playing tailgate the government. We announced funding for the Geelong bypass. The Labor Party said, `No, we refuse to fund that. It is not a national road.' In his tailgating style, Mr Martin Ferguson, the Labor spokesman, decided he would fund Geelong. He was tailgating out near Deer Park shortly after and decided they would finally make an announcement about Deer Park.

answer.para: What is interesting, however, is that we went around Australia announcing significant road funding increases, road construction increases in particular—an average increase of 74.7 per cent for road construction for the coming five years—and the 61 per cent increase in road spending in Queensland, for example—and the state budget is being handed down by their Treasurer as we speak—was described as `inadequate and mean' by the transport minister there. I throw out a challenge not only to Mr Lucas, the Queensland transport minister, and the Queensland government but to all Labor state governments—

talk.start.para: —Which is all of them.

—They are all Labor governments and they are all, with very few exceptions, quite inadequate at funding roads. I say to Mr Lucas now—I say to each one of them—`Let's see the colour of the Queensland government's money and their commitment to roads by announcing this afternoon a 61 per cent increase in the Queensland road budget.'

answer.para: The record of the South Australian government, who were incredibly ungrateful for a 43 per cent increase in road funding in South Australia—the biggest increase in road funding in South Australian history, on top of a 26 per cent increase for local road funding in South Australia—has seen reductions in regional and rural road spending and no new overtaking lanes. The federal government is building 17 overtaking lanes on the Sturt Highway. The South Australian government is not building a single overtaking lane in South Australia. I say to the South Australians: `If you are serious about road funding, match our increase of 43 per cent and build some roads. Match our black spot program'—another $44.5 million—`and match our Roads to Recovery projects.'

The record of the Western Australian government—another Labor government that criticised our road spending—is a reduction of just under $300 million in their road budget. The federal government is increasing road investment, increasing road spending and building new important road projects across the country, and Labor is ripping the guts out of them. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister advise the Senate when Australian officials in Washington or Canberra first became aware of Red Cross concerns about the treatment of prisoners at Guantanamo Bay? Can he further inform the Senate of who raised those concerns—the Red Cross themselves or representatives of the detained Australians?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —I am not sure whether that is a trick question—I have been asked it in my capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. For the first time there seems to be an introduction of suggestion that Australian officials in Washington might have some relevance to the issue. I think it would probably be sensible for me to refer that issue to the foreign minister. I can say that the Red Cross put down a report in February covering detention practices in Iraq from March to November of last year. That report was presented in Iraq to the CPA and to the occupying powers—Britain and the United States. That report was developed in part from a number of visits that had taken place during the preceding months and the preparation of certain working documents.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I asked a specific question of the minister. I notice he is rambling a bit. I give him an opportunity now to come back to the specific question that I asked in relation to the prisoners in Guantanamo Bay.
—There is no point of order. The minister has 2½ minutes yet. I am sure he will be coming back to the question.

—I will just finish what I was saying about Iraq because that seems to be the preoccupation of the Labor Party to date. I was going to say before I was rudely interrupted that working papers had also been presented from visits in late October to the coalition military authority in Iraq. There were some Australian military officials who had access on both of those occasions—on the occasion of the presentation of the working papers and on the occasion of the presentation of the final report. In relation to Guantanamo Bay, I do not have the specific answer but I can provide some assistance.
—We would never have guessed.

—Okay, I'll be honest. I do not know when the Red Cross first brought their concerns to the attention of Australian officials in relation to Guantanamo Bay, but I will seek that response from the foreign minister.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I wonder if the minister could supply to the Senate the nature of the concerns raised in relation to the treatment of Australian prisoners in Guantanamo Bay and also supply to the Senate copies of those reports.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —I will refer that to the foreign minister as well.

—My question is to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Senator Vanstone, and goes to the issue of Indigenous owned property and the Lands Acquisition Act. Minister, isn't it true that since 1990 ATSIC, and more particularly Indigenous people, have had control over Indigenous property through the exemption in the Lands Acquisition Act that says that ATSIC and Indigenous people are free to conduct their own property transactions without reference to the act or any other body, including the minister? Given that the properties under question belong to Indigenous people, what is the justification for your government's decision to take control of all Indigenous owned property by amending the Lands Acquisition Regulations in this way? Did the government undertake any consultation before making this decision? Was this decision discussed with the ATSIC Board of Commissioners or ATSIC councils and community organisations, and did they concur with that decision?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —Senator Ridgeway, you will understand well that there is a significant portion of property held by ATSIC in various ways that is quite rightly identified as Indigenous property, and in my view it will stay that way. Some will go to the ILC and some to IBA—that is, to the Indigenous Land Corporation and to Indigenous Business Australia—and I am not of the view that Indigenous property should be handled in any other way. But I will take the detail of your question on notice and come back to you if I have anything else to say.

answer.para: Senator Ridgeway there is one point I would make to you about what we seek to do in relation to Indigenous affairs. You would have heard me say before that it is not simply a question of mainstreaming, although that is just one mechanism for what we want to do, in the same way that Labor mainstreamed the health area some years ago. We want to do much more than that. We want to coordinate ourselves in a better way on a regional basis so that individual communities do not have to deal with a wide range of departments. We understand that the states and territories want to do the same, and we have all learned that through the COAG trials, so that Indigenous people will have less difficulty in dealing with a wide range of bureaucracies and so that we do not make it as difficult, as all of us have done for so long, for Indigenous people in rural and remote regions to get the proper assistance they need.

I understand that there are different views in relation to the abolition of ATSIC, although I notice that Mr Latham has said that he thought it should go and that he had lost confidence in it. From all the Indigenous people I have spoken to, it is my view that the vast majority feel the same way. Certainly in the communities I have visited I had one recently, on the weekend, who was concerned about it. But I accept that there would be more. I think the difference between this side and the other side in relation to Indigenous affairs is that people over here want to grab Indigenous votes. We want to give Indigenous people better value, and we will.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for the answer, but I am not sure whether she understood the question. I am referring to property held by community organisations. Isn't it true that a significant amount of property not previously held under caveat—for example, property bequeathed by a church, or groups or individuals—will now come under such a caveat? Doesn't the amendment to the regulations extend the government's reach beyond what was previously allowable? What is the legal reason or justification for making this type of decision? Given that the amendments to abolish ATSIC are still to be dealt with by the Senate, isn't this underhanded attempt to take control of Indigenous property just another example of the government's contempt for the Senate and contempt for Indigenous people? We are talking about property held in title by community organisations, not by the government, not by the Indigenous Land Corporation and certainly not by Indigenous Business Australia.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The detail of that question, especially in relation to the church groups you mentioned, I will take on notice. I do have to take exception to your view that this government treats either the Senate or Indigenous people, which in particular is my concern, with contempt.

—You did say that, Senator. I do not think you can judge things only by money, but this government has spent 29 per cent more in real dollars than the previous government ever did on Indigenous matters. We have had significant increases in the proportion of Indigenous kids going to year 12—about a one-third increase in the time we have been in government. There has been an increase of roughly the same proportion in the percentage of kids who go on to do bachelor and higher degree courses, so let us not live under some misunderstanding, Senator Ridgeway, as to which government has always provided better outcomes for Indigenous Australians, and always will. (Time expired)
—My question is to Senator Ellison, the Minister for Justice and Customs. I refer the minister to his comments on ABC television last night where he said:

quote.para: Well, he joined the NCA and not the ACC and the ACC's put in place enhanced measures. Your questions have been about the alleged corruption of the Australian Crime Commission. What I'm saying to you is that we, with the setting up of the Australian Crime Commission, have ensured that there will be secondees on a rotational basis, that the vetting will be enhanced.

question.para: Minister, isn't it a fact that the two officers identified on ABC television last night were working for the Australian Crime Commission, not the National Crime Authority? Minister, why should we have faith in the so-called enhanced vetting and rotational secondment processes of the Australian Crime Commission when these measures failed to avoid or detect the alleged corrupt activities of these officers?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —As I recall, the question put to me during the interview—and I do not think the question was broadcast on last night's program—was in the context of the measures that the Australian Crime Commission has put in place. What I was indicating was that these two officers had joined the NCA and were then transferred to the ACC when it was set up. The point I was making was a very clear one: the Australian Crime Commission has put in place enhanced measures in relation to vetting people who want to be seconded to the ACC or who want to work for the ACC. We have adopted a rotational basis—that is, to shorten the periods of time that people would work with the ACC and to keep that rotation going. I think I touched on that in the answer I gave to Senator Ludwig. The reason behind that is obvious: it is to avoid entrenched bad practices gaining a foothold in an organisation such as the ACC. There is vetting that goes into the financial affairs of the applicant concerned and other assessments. We have also looked at professional standards, which the Commonwealth Ombudsman has looked at, and an independent committee has been set up in that regard.

answer.para: The ACC has put in place measures which have been an improvement on the NCA. These two officers joined the NCA and were then transferred to the ACC. The point I was making was that they did not join the ACC in the first instance—they came from the NCA. That was a significant point. The other significant point is that these two officers were serving police officers with the New South Wales Police Force and the Victorian Police Force. Their status now is a matter of investigation, but these two detectives were secondees. They did not form a part of the two-thirds staff that I mentioned earlier. The ACC has in place many checks and balances. These were gone through when we debated the legislation, when the parliamentary joint committee looked at the setting up of the ACC. I would remind the Senate that it enjoyed bipartisan support.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware that the allegations against the two officers serving with the Australian Crime Commission include allegations of corrupt and illegal activity organised and carried out in conjunction with Australian Crime Commission operations, using Australian Crime Commission police mobile telephones and Australian Crime Commission police vehicles? Minister, given the heavy involvement of Australian Crime Commission resources in the substance of these allegations, why is it that the ACC only became aware of these alleged activities when they were alerted by state police corruption bodies?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —I understand the original source of the information came from an informant. I will not go into that detail for operational reasons, but the use of ACC resources is of course a matter of concern. That is why the ACC immediately instituted an independent inquiry. As I have said, I will look very closely at the report that the inquiry delivers to the Commonwealth Ombudsman. If action is needed, the Commonwealth government will act.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —In response to a series of questions on the Asia Pacific Space Centre from Senator Faulkner and Senator Carr in March this year, I advised the Senate that the Commonwealth had not made any payments to APSC and that around $5 million had been spent on common user infrastructure on Christmas Island. I based that advice on information provided to me by the Department of Transport and Regional Services. Following a recent reconciliation of expenditure by that department, I can confirm that my previous advice that no payments had been made to APSC was correct; however, DOTARS has advised that expenditure on common use infrastructure as at March 2004 in fact totalled $7.4 million. On 18 May this year I wrote to Senator Faulkner and Senator Carr in this regard. The break-up of that expenditure was detailed in those letters, which I am happy to table. I reiterate that the entire sum has been spent on providing common use infrastructure such as a new port and a road that will benefit the wider Christmas Island community. No funding will be provided to APSC unless and until appropriate performance milestones have been achieved.

debateinfo.title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: TAKE NOTE OF ANSWERS

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Family and Community Services (Senator Patterson) to questions without notice asked by Senators Collins, Forshaw and Moore today relating to family payment debts.

speech.para: The point I will highlight as I commence my comments is that the government has had three years to reform its deeply flawed family payments system. In those three years, more than 2.9 million incorrect payments have been made to families—that is, 56 per cent of all payments totalling $2.5 billion have been wrong, and 1.6 million families have been overpaid an average of $900 each year. That means that the government has recovered a total of $1.5 billion from families through the stripping of their tax returns, the issuing of debt notices and garnisheeing of future payments. The one thing the government system seemingly cannot do is to pay families their correct entitlement when they need it each fortnight—I stress: when they need it each fortnight. Even the government's research tells it that families do not want to deal with annual assessments of their circumstances—they want financial support when they need it and in accordance with their circumstances. This is the component that the government cannot grapple with.

In the recent federal budget the government tried to paper over the problem by providing this $600 payment, but I hope Australian families will recall that the $1,000 payment that the government gave before the last election lasted for only one year. This time families will receive $600 before this election and a promised $600 after it to flow through the system—the government claims—as an additional family benefits payment. But, when we look at the detail, we discover that that additional $600 will not be indexed in future in the same way that family payments were in the past. Senator Patterson today promised that this $600 would maintain its real value. The trick, though, is in what she means by the `real value'. It is clear from her answers today that she continues to fudge on that issue. I suspect it is because she got dudded in cabinet. She knows that family payments have been indexed by a wage related measure for many years. She knows that the trick—perhaps it was Treasury, it seems that FaCS was not aware of this trick when we questioned them in estimates—of making this $600 a cushion on wage related indexation is the fraud that the Howard government is now running. If indexation had occurred in the way the old formula applied, and you compare it to how indexation will work with this new figure, this additional $600 will disappear in five years. That is the fraud that the government is now peddling. The government has refused to come back to the Senate Community Affairs References Committee with the detail following the estimates process last week. Senator Patterson indicated that, if necessary, the government would legislate to maintain the real value of this additional $600, but what the government still has not dealt with is that the change to the indexation formula changes the value of family payments across the board, not just this $600. This $600 will be a cushion on future increases and there will not be the benefit in the system that this government claims.

If Senator Patterson had said today quite frankly and quite clearly that the indexation of the family benefit would continue on the same basis that it had in the past then she would have avoided this fraud. She did not do that today and that is why she must have been dudded in cabinet. CPI is what the minister refers to, yet anybody who has been around the indexation of family support and pensions knows that, if you want to maintain the real value of pensions and assistance, you link it to a wage related measure. We know this problem, for instance, in relation to the child-care benefit. We know that the affordability of the child-care benefit has been in decline because it is indexed solely to the CPI. There is a long history of indexation across pensions and benefits and this government— (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Isn't it interesting that Senator Collins can come in here, day after day, whingeing, whining and carrying on as she does about this issue, yet at no stage has she released a policy. I think she is the shadow minister—I am not too sure; she hides her light under a bushel pretty well—so why hasn't she released a policy? Here they are after eight years of opposition and the shadow minister is about to prance out of this place, still without a policy. Also, this shadow minister, this pretend shadow minister, has not been able to account for Labor, when they were in government, never giving anyone a top-up.

speech.para: The Labor opposition quite clearly say in this argument that, if someone provides the wrong information and they are given taxpayers money as a consequence, they should be allowed to keep it at the expense of every other taxpayer. The government do not agree with that. The government say that, if someone provides the incorrect information and they get something to which they are not entitled, the other taxpayers of Australia deserve that money to be put back into the barrel for those who do require it. Additionally, when the Labor Party were in government—and because there is no policy there is no indication that they would change—if someone underestimated their income, they were never, ever given a top-up. Under this government, they are. It is a very marked difference.

Yet, we have Senator Collins coming in here and screeching from the rafters about things that are completely and utterly wrong. They are wrong from the point of view that Senator Collins does not understand for one moment what the government initiative is all about—no wonder she cannot write a policy. Around two million families with three and a half million children will benefit from the family tax benefit—but she does not understand that—and the vast majority of those families with dependent children are now eligible for family assistance.

The most important thing that she does not understand is that the new More Help for Families measures will provide an additional $19.2 billion in assistance over five years. This is the largest package ever put in place by any Australian government. If she thinks that a Labor government can do better, then let her put her cards on the table. Do not come in here and screech about it. Put your cards on the table. Let us see the policy. Let us compare what we have done, put into practice and put in the budget with they would do if they were ever given the opportunity to take the government benches again.

But, no, we cannot compare one with the other because this incompetent shadow minister cannot possibly put together a policy that we can look at. With the government's policy, about two million eligible families will receive a one-off payment of $600 per child for family tax benefit part A—and other eligible children—before 30 June 2004. From 1 July 2004, there will be an ongoing FTB part A supplement payment of $600 per child, which will increase the base and maximum rates of the FTB part A. It is as clear as crystal in the budget papers.

What is the alternative? We do not know. We have not the faintest idea. In this short debate that we now have following question time, it will be interesting to see whether one member of the opposition can tell us what they would do in government that would be different, whether they would allow people to get overpayments and keep them at the expense of every other taxpayer and whether they would adopt the government policy of top-ups if underpayments occurred. I will wait and see whether the Labor opposition have a policy and how it will differ from the policy that the government have put in place which will benefit over two million families in this country.

talk.start.para: —It is always interesting to note in these debates and very often during question time how anxious the government are to hear the Labor Party's policies. The reason they are so anxious to hear the Labor Party's policies is that they want to pinch them. If you go back and look at some of the things that we have announced, you will find that when the Labor Party announce a policy this government steals it. For instance, only recently Mr Latham announced that the Labor Party would reform the parliamentary superannuation system. Who pinched that policy? It was none other than the Prime Minister. The Labor Party announced that we would make changes in respect of ATSIC. The Prime Minister followed that by announcing that he would follow our lead. We have announced in the past policies regarding the maternity allowance. We said the baby bonus—

—Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: the motion before you is to debate the answers provided by Senator Patterson today in question time. My point of order, therefore, is Senator Forshaw is not debating that. If he wishes to announce his policy on the issue relating to Senator Patterson's answers, then that is fine.

—Senator Knowles, you know there is no point of order. These are fairly wide-ranging debates. I am sure Senator Forshaw, if he is not there already, will get to the point he is making to the Senate shortly.

—I am getting to the very issue in respect of the motion, but one has to deal with these false assertions from the government about lack of policy first. The Labor Party is developing its policy and will announce it in the fullness of time—in particular, when we get the election date out of this government. But let me deal with the questions that were asked of Senator Patterson during question time and the lack of answers that were given—particularly to the one that I asked. We have asked the minister to provide the detail as to how she can be so confident that the value of the $600 payment in family tax benefit A will not be eroded because of changes to the indexation formula. The minister stood up in question time today and said: `You don't need to worry about that. It won't happen.' We have asked the department and we have asked the minister for the detail to be provided. We were assured at estimates that it would be provided. We are still waiting for the answer. The minister's response today was, `The department's too busy trying to get this money out into people's letterboxes during the next few weeks.' The minister says they are too busy to provide us with the detail of this pre-election bribe. The fact of the matter is the detail should be available. It should have been available as part of the development of this policy announcement in the budget.

speech.para: The reason we do not have an answer, I suspect, is that the minister and the department have been caught out. During the estimates process this issue was brought to light during the questioning of the departmental officials, and the minister did not really understand. And she still does not understand. The fact of the matter is that any value arising out of this initial one-off payment will be eroded over the course of the next five years because of the changes to the indexation arrangements that would have otherwise applied to family tax benefits.

Senator Collins, in her excellent speech on this issue, pointed out that this government has presided over a system which is giving with one hand and taking back with the other. The only response you get from members of the government, such as Senator Knowles, is to attack the messenger. But Australian families know that even when they advise Centrelink of changes to their income circumstances, even when they comply with the requirements that are laid down, they often find they still end up with a debt. It is no fault of theirs; it is the fault of this system. We have a situation now where 1.6 million Australian families have an average debt to Centrelink of $900 per year. Okay, this government has tried to fix the problem for the short term by paying a one-off $600 payment, but what those families have to understand is there is a sting in the tail—that this government gives with one hand and takes away with another. And that is the cruellest trick you can play on the Australian people. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —As I listened across the chamber to Senator Collins and Senator Forshaw, a phrase that was made famous by the late President Reagan sprang to mind, a phrase he made popular during the 1980 presidential debate. He famously said, `There you go again.' There indeed goes this opposition once again desperately trying to strip some gloss off what has been extremely good news for Australian families in the last few months in the form of additional payments to them under family tax benefits. There have been significant improvements to their financial positions, there have been significant increases in their security and there has been a significant increase in their capacity to meet the cost of living. With the increase in the amount of money available to Australian families, these families are significantly more reassured by the action they have seen from this government than by the rhetoric they hear from the opposition.

speech.para: The fact is that, however you look at the situation, Australian families today are in toto better off under the present regime and the present arrangements for family tax payments and family support than they ever were under Labor—and not by small degrees but by a country mile. There is more money available to Australian families for income support—$19.2 billion for the next five years—announced under the More Help for Families package, there is wider eligibility and there are larger payments. More Australian families positively benefit from these arrangements. I ask those opposite: do they really think Australian families are focusing on the questions they are raising—these relatively marginal questions, with respect, about overpayments—or do they think Australian families are focusing on the big picture of how payments have improved and how their position has improved under the coalition government? If you think they are focused on the former, you are kidding yourselves.

We keep coming back to this question of overpayments. Labor says there are overpayments to Australian families that have to be repaid to the government and it shows the government is mean and niggardly and that it wants to get this money back. Let me remind people that top-up payments to Australian families who missed out were not available under the Labor Party government. If you underestimated your income under a Labor administration, then too bad, stiff cheese, you lost out. Today people in that position can receive a top-up benefit, but the corollary of that, the other side of that coin, is that overpayments need to be addressed, and that is what this government does with its policy.

I ask members opposite: what is the practical alternative to recovering overpayments made to anybody who is a beneficiary of the Australian government or any government, for that matter? What is the alternative to recovering those overpayments if they are made? I do not know. We have not heard what Labor's alternative is. We do not know what Labor are going to do—if they ever miraculously squeak into office somehow—to address this issue. Are they going to forgive those sorts of debts? Are they going to say, `No, it's all right'? Or are they going to do what they have done in the past and say that there are no top-up payments for Australian families and that if you underestimate your income, too bad, you do not get a top-up. The other side of that coin is that you can keep an overpayment. Is that what you are going to do? Let us know. Let us find out.

I know that a previous Labor minister once tried to implement a policy of no collection. I recall that many years ago, when he was responsible for the ACT, Tom Uren made the statement in public that he thought it was unfair that ACT public housing tenants should have to pay outstanding back rent. What happened? There was an explosion in unpaid rent to the ACT Housing Trust—so much so that the succeeding minister had to reverse the policy and set about recovering millions of dollars in unpaid rent to the Australian government as administrator of the ACT Housing Trust. So Labor's policies do not actually bear any scrutiny. We do not even know what Labor's policies are in detail. No-one is fooled by this exercise. We know that you do not have an alternative. You are trying to take the gloss off what has been a very good policy that has provided great benefits to the Australian community and Australian families. You are failing miserably in that exercise and you are coming back to this issue by trying to find some currency and some mileage in it. Frankly, I do not think that anyone sees that you are succeeding in that exercise.

talk.start.para: —I rise also to take note of answers given by Senator Patterson today. Here we go again. We have been talking about the system for a number of years now—in fact, since it was first introduced. The system that was introduced to pay family tax under this government is basically flawed. It is not gloss. In fact, the only gloss in this system is the one-off payment which has been introduced—and that is gloss. For all the families in Australia who will be receiving the one-off payment over the next two weeks, that will be gloss. However, what is below the gloss is significant. Debt is not a marginal issue.

speech.para: We have a statement by the Minister for Family and Community Services that `an amazing amount of money' will be given to Australian families over the next couple of months. One component of that amazing amount of money that will be spent on this issue is a significant advertising campaign. We do not know all the details of the campaign. We have asked about it, but we are still waiting to see what the details will be. But, interestingly enough, one of the reasons for the advertising campaign which we discussed at Senate estimates was precisely the fact that Australian families are confused by the system of family payments. It is not an easy system to understand. One of the reasons that the government must spend about $20 million—an amazing amount of money on advertising for this component alone—is that people do not understand the system. We have heard before in this place and also in Senate estimates about a general acceptance that the system is complex and that some people get caught out by it—not a small marginal number. I take issue with the fact that debt can be considered to be small and marginal when people are traumatised by receiving information from the government that they owe money.

In this place we have discussed what we consider to be the inbuilt flaw in the system, which indicates that people are in a situation of having to make a choice. They have to guesstimate their forward income, and on the basis of that guesstimate their payments are made. We know that the vast majority of people in the country who take up this payment prefer to have it paid on a fortnightly basis. There is no question about that. Senator Patterson has agreed with that. People see the value of getting that regular income. However, the real kick to this process is that, if you have not calculated your income correctly at the beginning of the financial year or at times throughout the financial year, you will have a significant debt at the end of the time. There is no question about this. We have heard from previous ministers that a debt is a debt is a debt. We say that the system must be enhanced to ensure that people are not caught out by this debt.

Amidst the amazing amount of money to be spent on the advertising campaign around the glossy one-off payments that are to be brought in by the end of this financial year and the glossy growth of the payment over the next couple of financial years, there must be some awareness in the community that you need to consider that a debt may be accruing. We asked quite directly whether the advertising would promote some clear understanding of how debts are accrued. We also asked quite a specific question as to whether this year alone there will be a clear understanding that tax refunds will not be stripped to repay the debt that people may have accrued. You would all understand that in the past this has been a significant issue that we have raised. People have come to our offices and complained that they have received notices from the Taxation Office at the end of the financial year saying that, because they have a family payment debt, their refund caused by other purposes will be stripped and they will not have access to that money. We are trying to understand whether this year—quite significantly a year where we could be deep in an election campaign—the advertising campaign will say that this year alone you will not be stripped.

The minister consistently says that people on this side of the chamber do not understand. We do understand, Minister. We are asking specific questions. We want to get the system to work. But it is not just us who have to understand but the community, the people who are receiving these payments and the people who will be benefited by the gloss but will also be damaged by any debt that they accrue. This is the real issue. This is not some kind of stunt or a whinge or a whine. These are direct questions to the government. Have you seen how the debt will be worked out? How will families be told about it? Will they be helped through this process so that they will not be further traumatised by a payment that is their right? (Time expired)
Question agreed to.

talker.name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
Senator BARTLETT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads (Senator Ian Campbell) to a question without notice asked by Senator Allison today relating to the availability of an emergency contraceptive drug.

speech.para: The question went to what is a matter of very significant public health importance, and something that is of particular importance to the health of many women in Australia—that is, the announced desire of the Minister for Health and Ageing to reverse the decision that was made some months back to allow what is commonly known as the `morning after pill' to be made available through pharmacies. Probably what is most noteworthy is that the minister chose not to answer the question at all and made no comment whatsoever on what is a very controversial and quite widely publicised announcement by the health minister. I think it is extraordinary that Minister Campbell suggested that he had no information on the matter, no comment on the matter and no view on the matter, and simply referred it to the health minister. That is unsatisfactory and I suggest it is very unlikely that there was no information and no awareness on the part of the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing in this chamber about that particular matter. It is a matter of great significance.

If you examine Minister Abbott's explanation as to why he wants to reverse this decision and restrict the availability of the morning after pill and the other announcements that he has made, which he has been forced to back down on—according to reports—by his own party room, to attempt to contravene the privacy of young people who seek information and help from a doctor, there is clearly an agenda here on the part of the health minister—an ideological agenda, a narrow agenda driven by a narrow idea of morality that is very concerning.

I noted with great interest the comment made by at least one Liberal Party member in the weekend papers suggesting that this agenda from the health minister was directly linked to the agreement that the health minister made with some Independent crossbench senators on his Medicare safety net legislation. That is an extremely worrying suggestion. I am sure many people had that suspicion, but the fact that the statement was made by a Liberal Party member gives much greater weight to that suspicion. It is a classic example of why the Senate needs to act responsibly, openly and transparently about important policy matters.

It is no secret that the Democrats negotiated extensively with the government about their proposed Medicare safety net. We negotiated and achieved significant gains on the government's Medicare proposals—extra incentives for bulk-billing, extra assistance for allied health—without compromising the fundamental and integral component of Medicare, which is its universality. Those sets of negotiations in the areas which had been agreed to by the health minister were undercut by Independent crossbench senators here. You had to wonder at the time why they would undercut something and agree to something that actually achieved less assistance for allied health and that unnecessarily destroyed the universality of Medicare by creating a two-tiered safety net, the flaws of which were outlined quite clearly in a Senate committee report which one of those Independent senators had signed off on.

So you do have to ask the question: what else was there in that agreement at least for one, if not more, of those senators that made them feel it was a better result for them than what otherwise would have been achieved? Why did they allow the fundamental principle of universality to be dramatically compromised to achieve something that was less than the government was already going to agree to? You then have to ask the question: were there other side deals? Were there other issues that were not announced at the time that were part of that agreement? This is not the first time that this minister has subsequently raised issues that are clearly very narrow, morality driven—I use that term in a very narrow sense—and ideologically driven. It is a conservative morality agenda that has been put forward. Statements were made not long after that that threats to family planning funding had been drawn attention to in the past.

This is a very serious matter and the Democrats are pleased that the minister has failed in his agenda to attack the privacy rights of young people seeking to go to the doctor who are still very concerned that the government will seek to find a way to restrict the rights of women to access a full range of contraceptive assistance and simple assistance on a basic health matter, such as the morning after pill. (Time expired)
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

quote.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned notes the inadequate numbers of livestock available for Australian slaughter, food consumption and hides; the increase in Australian abattoir closures; the growing negative economic, employment and social impacts on rural Australia; and the unnecessary suffering endured by Australian livestock because of this nation's pursuit of trade and financial benefits at any cost. Your petitioners call on the members of the Senate to end the live export trade now in favour of developing an Australian chilled and frozen halal and kosher carcass trade using humane slaughtering practices.

talk.start.para: Senator Bartlett (from 355 citizens).

petitioninfo.title: Defence: Involvement in Overseas Conflict Legislation

quote.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned calls on the members of the Senate to support the Defence Amendment (Parliamentary Approval for Australian Involvement in Overseas conflict) Bill introduced by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Andrew Bartlett and the Democrats' Foreign Affairs spokesperson, Senator Natasha Stott Despoja.

Presently, the Prime Minister, through a Cabinet decision and the authority of the Defence Act, has the power to send Australian troops to an overseas conflict without the support of the United Nations, the Australian Parliament or the Australian people.

The Howard Government has been the first Government in our history to go to war without majority Parliament support. It is time to take the decision to commit troops to overseas conflict out of the hands of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and place it with the Parliament.

talk.start.para: Senator Bartlett (from 197 citizens).

quote.para: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

That sufferers of Osteoporosis are forced to pay large amounts for the supply of treatment, due to the Criteria, which is enforced by the Government through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Board which states “A vertebral fracture is defined as a 20% or greater reduction in height of the anterior or mid portion of a vertebral body relative to the posterior height of that body, or, a 20% or greater reduction in any of these heights compared to the vertebral body above or below the affected vertebral body”.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to please amend this criteria: We request that diagnosis of Osteoporosis be sufficient to have treatment offered on PBS.

talk.start.para: Senator Humphries (from 162 citizens).

quote.para: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

petition.para: 1. We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the Australian national flag.
2. We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the nation's history.

quote.para: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

talk.start.para: Senator Kemp (from four citizens).

names.name: Senator McGauran;Senator Moore;Senator Patterson;Senator Robert Ray;Senator Troeth

quote.para: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

That the current intention of the Government to abolish the rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to exercise their right of self self-determination and self-management, will severely disadvantage Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
Your petitioners request that the Senate:

petition.para: 1. oppose any legislation for the abolition of ATSIC unless and until an alternative elected representative structure, developed and approved by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples is put in place and which would, at the same time assume the function of ATSIC.
2. oppose any move to appoint an advisory committee as contrary to the rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to elect their own representatives.

3. oppose any move to diminish, dismantle, destroy and/or erode the principles of self-determination and self-management since any such action would turn back the clock on hard won rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
4. strongly defend these rights of self-determination and self-management of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people previously supported by the Australian Parliament.
5. oppose any move to main-stream services for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as this too would severely disadvantage Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

talk.start.para: Senator McGauran (from 12 citizens),
Senator Moore (from three citizens),
Senator Patterson (from 84 citizens),
Senator Robert Ray (from 26 citizens) and
Senator Troeth (from 11 citizens).

quote.para: To the honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia undersigned draws the attention of the Senate:

Legislation that will allocate the share of federal funding going to government and non-government schools will soon be debated in Parliament. Currently, about 70% of this funding goes to 30% of total student population (non-government schools), while the remaining 30% of funding goes to 70% of total student population (government schools).
The States Grants Act needs to be amended to make the share for government school students fairer. We need our public schools to be well resourced.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to:
Ensure that the funding policies of the Commonwealth Government are reformed to provide increased and fairer funding for public schools.

talk.start.para: The President (from 27 citizens).

quote.para: To the honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate:

For over 150 years our country has been served by a comprehensive and inclusive system of public education. Public education has contributed to successful lives and democratic social development in an Australia which is highly skilled and economically strong. It has built our national identity and democratic traditions and given the capacity for active citizenship to the Australian people.
All of this has been possible only because the system has enjoyed public confidence and public investment.

At this time both are under threat Public confidence has been undermined by divisive attacks and public investment has been distorted by an unfair system of federal funding which favours an already well-off minority to the detriment of those in genuine need.
We therefore call on all Senators to condemn these unjust attacks, and to:

petition.para: accept national responsibility to provide priority in funding to public schools to enable them to continue to provide high quality education to all, regardless of wealth, location, ethnicity, religion or special needs; and,

replace the current unfair SES funding model with a new Commonwealth and State system which provides enhanced educational resources to schools allocated on the basis of educational need and which ends public funding to wealthy schools which are already well resourced.

talk.start.para: The President (from 19 citizens).

petitioninfo.title: East Timor: Oil and Gas Fields

quote.para: To the Honourable The President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

We the undersigned appeal to the Australian Government regarding its conduct of negotiations with the Government of Timor Leste on the maritime boundary between the two countries and sharing of the Timor Sea oil and gas revenue.
We pray the Senate ensures the Australian Government:

petition.para: 1. negotiates a fair and equitable maritime boundary with Timor Leste according to current international law and the provisions of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS),
2. responds to Timor Leste's request for more regular meetings to settle the maritime boundary dispute between the two countries within a more reasonable timeframe,
3. returns Australia to the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice and UNCLOS for the adjudication, of maritime boundary,

4. commits to hold intrust (escrow) revenues received from the disputed areas immediately outside the Joint. Petroleum Development Area (RDA) of the 20 May 2002 Timor Sea Treaty for further apportionment between Australia and Timor Leste after the maritime boundary dispute between the two countries has been settled.

talk.start.para: The President (from four citizens).

subdebate.1.para: Senators O'Brien, Ridgeway, Nettle and Lees to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That—
(1) A select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Administration of Indigenous Affairs, be appointed to inquire into and report, by 31 October 2004, on the following matters:
(a) the provisions of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 2004;
(b) the proposed administration of Indigenous programs and services by mainstream departments and agencies; and
(c) related matters.

(2) The committee consist of 8 senators, 3 nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 3 nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, 1 nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, and 1 nominated by minority groups and independent senators.
(3) The committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that not all members have been duly nominated and appointed and notwith-standing any vacancy.
(4) The chair of the committee be elected by the committee from the members nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate.
(5) The deputy chair of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair.
